The ongoing hunting pressure, habitat encroachment and human settlement within such forest reserves pose severe threats to the survival of these remaining populations.

In Guinea, C. polykomos has been extirpated in several localities, including protected areas. In the Boke region, a 2005 RAP survey (Eriksson and Kpoghomou 2006) found no evidence of the species' presence, although it was formerly reported from the region by local people. A rapid survey of primates conducted from November to December 2015 also failed to find evidence of the species in the CGB-Halco concession (WCF 2015). Surveys conducted between April 2012 and February 2014 confirmed the presence of C. polykomos in the Lebekere sub-prefecture, in the northern sector of the Fouta Djallon mountain range. The ongoing loss and fragmentation of this habitat suggest that the population is in decline (Fernandez-Garcia et al. 2018).

In Guinea-Bissau, the species occupies patches of forest where anthropogenic habitat loss, habitat fragmentation and poaching pressure are high (Minhós et al. 2013). In Cantanhez National Park in southwestern Guinea-Bissau, Minhós et al. (2013) estimated an effective population size of 251–575 based on an analysis of the mtDNA hypervariable region (HVR). A 2015 recce survey in Dulombi National Park reported the presence of the species at a low encounter rate of 0.33 groups/km (Bersacola et al. 2018). The presence of C. polykomos in the Boe region has been reported in a 2013 survey (Hoogveld 2013).

In Liberia, the species has already been depleted in most protected and unprotected areas. Subsistence and commercial hunting pressure have increased during the last decade and illegal gold mining threatens the future of protected areas (Tweh et al. 2015). In Nimba County, north-central Liberia, Bene et al. (2013a) reported that they did not encounter any hunters carrying carcasses of this species in their market visits, indicating that it has been depleted in most, if not all forests in this area. C. polykomos was not observed during a recce survey conducted in November-December 2011 in the forest patches of the Sime Darby concession covering four counties (Gbarpolu, Bomi, Bong and Grand Cape Mount) (Bene et al. 2013b). During a 2014 biomonitoring survey in the Grebo-Krahn National Park, the species was encountered at a very low rate (0.08 groups/km; WCF 2014). During another survey conducted from January-August 2017 in the Krahn-Bassa National Forest, C. polykomos was also encountered at a very low rate (0.03 groups/km; WCF 2017). In Sapo National Park, a 10-month biomonitoring survey conducted in 2002 yielded a mean average sighting rate of 0.13/km, with a decrease in the monthly average recording of this species (Waitkuwait 2003). The species was heard twice in North Loma National Forest and sighted three times in the Grebo National Forest during a Rapid Assessment Program survey conducted from 16 November to 12 December 2005 in North Loma National Forest, Gola National Forest and Grebo National Forest (Barrie et al. 2005).

In Sierra Leone, insufficient data are available to assess the current status of this species. Nevertheless, indications are that it is very rare and its distribution patchy (Brncic et al. 2010). In Gola National Forest Park, C. polykomos was encountered in the course of wildlife surveys made before and after the 1991–2001 civil war (Davies 1987, Klop et al. 2008, Lindsell et al. 2011), but the use of different survey methods, and the manner in which auditory and visual encounter data are presented in their reports, make it impossible to gauge with precision any changes in population numbers. In a nationwide survey of chimpanzees conducted from January 2009 to May 2010, C. polykomos was encountered or reported in the Kambui Hills Forest Reserve, the Kangari Hills Forest Reserve, the Loma Mountains National Park, the Nimini Hills Forest Reserve, the Outamba-Kilimi National Park, the Tingi Hills Fotrest Reserve and the Western Area Forest Reserve (Brncic 2011). The species also occurs in the Tiwai Island Wildlife Sanctuary (Dasilva 1989), a site which was not included in Brncic's survey.

In southeastern Senegal, no study to date has confirmed the presence of C. polykomos, although this species is expected to occur along the Guinean coast (Oates et al. 2008)
range: Colobus polykomos is found in West Africa, from southern Senegal, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, to the Sassandra River in Côte d’Ivoire (Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005). Colobus p. dollmani is probably a hybrid between C. polykomos and C. vellerosus that occurred in the narrow contact between the Bandama and the Sassandra rivers, but is probably now extinct (Gonedelé Bi pers. obs. 2015).
useTrade: Uncontrolled hunting throughout the range for bushmeat and the commercial bushmeat trade.
conservationActions:
Colobus polykomos is listed as Class A under the African Convention and under Appendix II of CITES. It is found in a number of protected areas, including Sapo National Park (Liberia), Grebo-Krahn National Park (Liberia), Gola National Park (Liberia), Gola Forest National Park (Sierra Leone), Loma Mountains National Park (Sierra Leone), Tiwai Island Wildlife Sanctuary (Sierra Leone), Taï National Park (Côte d'Ivoire), and Cantanhez National Park (Guinea-Bissau). Rigorous law enforcement against poaching in protected areas is needed to ensure the survival of this species; permanent research stations in protected areas would greatly assist conservation efforts.

Although C. polykomos is found at very low densities in many of the forests where it still occurs, accurate estimates of the size and density of these populations are needed. Systematic surveys should be conducted in Grebo-Krahn NP in Liberia, Gola Rainforest NP and Loma Mountains NP in Sierra Leone, Cantanhez and Dulombi NP in Guinea-Bissau. In Cote d'Ivoire, the Tai Monkey Project, Centre Suisse de Recherches Scientifiques en Cote d'Ivoire (CSRS) and the Wild Chimpanzee Foundation have been making efforts to conserve the primates of the Tai National Park for several decades.

rationale:
Colobus angolensis is listed as Vulnerable. Despite a very large geographic range, the species is threatened in most parts of its range by habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation caused mainly by collection of timber and fuelwood, conversion of forest to farmland, the expansion of human settlements and encroachment due to a fast growing human population (Bocian and Anderson 2013, McDonald et al. in prep).

Hunting is also a major threat to C. angolensis, particularly in Central Africa. It is targeted for bushmeat because of its large size. Despite the existence of largely intact, suitable and protected habitat in the Domaine de Chasse de Swa-Kibula, southwestern DRC, C. a. angolensis became locally extinct before 1990 due to unsustainable hunting (Dino 2014). Although hunting may be a particularly high threat in the Congo Basin, a number of other populations have already been extirpated from suitable habitats elsewhere, suggesting unsustainable levels of hunting [i.e. Arabuko Sokoke Forest, Kenya (Anderson 2004), North Pare Mountains (Doggart et al. 2008), and Pande Game Reserve, Tanzania (Burgess and Clarke 2000, Doggart 2003)]. In the unprotected Udzungwa Scarp Nature Reserve in the Udzungwa Mountains, Tanzania, Rovero et al. (2012, 2015) documented declines to near local extinction of C. a. sharpei due to hunting in a span of less than 10 years.

This taxon is suspected to have undergone a population decline exceeding 30% during the past 33 years (three generations), and is listed as Vulnerable using criterion A2cd. The threats that caused population reductions in the past are not reversible and have not been eliminated, nor will they be in the foreseeable future.
habitat: Colobus angolensis is a medium-sized, arboreal, folivorous primate. It lives in evergreen and semi-deciduous forest, including gallery forests, swamp forest, coastal forest, montane forest, and seasonally flooded forests. The species is rare in mangroves and bush-farm land (Bocian and Anderson 2007). They are generally found in small family groups (2–5 adults), but temporary aggregations of up to 300 animals have been reported in some subspecies. They feed primarily on leaves and seeds but also on fruit pulp, flowers and lichens (Bocian and Anderson 2013).
threats:
Colobus angolensis is threatened in most parts of its range by habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation caused mainly by collection of timber and fuelwood, conversion of forest to farmland, the expansion of human settlements and encroachment due to a fast growing human population (Bocian and Anderson 2013, McDonald et al. in prep.). Tourism development is a threat in Kenya and Tanzania.

Colobus angolensis is hunted for meat. Despite largely intact, suitable and protected habitat in the Domaine de Chasse de Swa-Kibula, southwestern DRC, C. a. angolensis became locally extinct before 1990 due to unsustainable hunting (Dino 2014). Although hunting may be a particularly high threat in the Congo Basin, a number of populations have already been extirpated from suitable habitats elsewhere, suggesting that unsustainable levels of hunting occurred [i.e. Arabuko Sokoke Forest, Kenya (Anderson 2004), North Pare Mountains (Doggart et al. 2008), and Pande Game Reserve, Tanzania (Burgess and Clarke 2000, Doggart 2003)]. In the unprotected Udzungwa Scarp Nature Reserve in the Udzungwa Mountains, Tanzania, Rovero et al. (2012, 2015) documented declines to near local extinction of C. a. sharpei due to hunting in a span of less than 10 years.

Illegal hunting for pelts has also been reported in Kenya and Tanzania (Anderson et al. 2007, Rovero et al. 2012).

The major threats for C. a. palliatus in residential areas on the southern Kenya coast are vehicle casualties and electrocution on power lines and transformers which, together, make up 60% of the animal welfare cases recorded by the NGO Colobus Conservation (Colobus Conservation unpubl. data 2017).
population: Colobus angolensis has a wide geographical range and can be locally abundant. Populations in the eastern part of the range are much more fragmented than populations across the Congo Basin. Densities vary widely (Bocian and Anderson 2013). In a comprehensive survey of the Kenyan range of the species, a total of 55 populations were located, with the Kenyan Colobus angolensis palliatus population estimated at 3,100–5,000 individuals (560–900 groups). In Shimba Hills National Park, southeastern Kenya, there are ca 15 individuals/km². At ca 2,400 individuals (Anderson et al. 2007), this is the largest population in Kenya. It exhibits at high density in Diani, a tourist suburban area with remnant forest and forest patches, where harassment is low. At least 10,000 C. a. sharpie are present in the Udzungwa Mountains, southern Tanzania (Rovero et al. 2009). Densities here are 0.8–5.0 groups km² (2.9–12.0 individuals km²) depending on threats and protection levels (Araldi et al. 2014). The Okapi Wildlife Reserve (central Ituri Forest, DRC) has a density of 16.7 individuals/km² (Bocian 1997).
range:
Colobus angolensis ranges from northeast Angola north to the Congo-Ubangui river system, eastwards (with a disjunct range) to the montane and coastal forests of Tanzania and southeastern Kenya (Anderson et al. 2007, Bocian and Anderson 2013). It occurs from sea level to 2,415 m asl (Nyungwe, Rwanda) in East Africa (Anderson et al. 2007, Fashing et al. 2007).

Eight subspecies are recognised, of which one is undescribed:

  • Colobus angolensis angolensis (Sclater’s Angola Colobus) occurs in northeastern Angola, north to the great bend of the Congo River and southwards to perhaps extreme northwestern Zambia (Bocian and Anderson 2013). C. a. angolensis became locally extinct before 1990 in the Domaine de Chasse de Swa-Kibula in southwestern DRC (Dino 2014).
  • Colobus angolensis cottoni (Powell-Cotton’s Angola Colobus) is endemic to DRC. It ranges from northeast of the Congo River, east to Lake Albert and north to the Uélé-Ubangui river system (it forms a hybrid zone with C. a. ruwenzorii in the southeast).
  • Colobus angolensis ruwenzorii (Rwenzori Angola Colobus) occurs along both sides of the Western (Albertine) Rift, from the Semiliki Valley and the Rwenzori Mountains of extreme eastern DRC and extreme western Uganda, to Rwanda, Burundi and northwestern Tanzania.
  • Colobus angolensis cordieri (Cordier’s Angola Colobus) is endemic to DRC between the Lowa River and Luama River from the Lualaba River in the western to near Lake Kivu in the east, where it forms a hybrid zone with C. a. ruwenzorii.
  • Colobus angolensis prigoginei (Prigogine’s Angola Colobus) is endemic to Mount Kabobo, eastern DRC.
  • Colobus angolensis palliatus (Peters’s Angola Colobus) is found in Kenya and Tanzania. It inhabits extreme southeastern Kenya in the north (Kwale County), the Eastern Arc Mountain blocks of East Usambara, Western Usambara, South Pare, Malundwe, Uluguru and Nguru. It is rare in Nguu. This subspecies is also found in the coastal forests of Tanzania north of the Rufiji River and riverine forest along the Rufiji River (Rogers 1981, Anderson et al. 2007).
  • Colobus angolensis sharpei (Sharpe’s Angola Colobus) inhabits areas around Lake Rukwa in southwestern Tanzania to north Malawi and northeastern Zambia. This subspecies might occur in northern Mozambique (Groves and Ting 2013).
  • Colobus angolensis ssp. nov. is presumably endemic to the Mahale Mountains, central western Tanzania (Nishida et al. 1981, Groves 2001, Grubb et al. 2003).
useTrade:
Colobus angolensis is hunted for meat, often at unsustainable levels. Populations have been extirpated from the Domaine de Chasse de Swa-Kibula in DRC (Dino 2014), Arabuko Sokoke Forest in Kenya (Anderson 2004), North Pare Mountains and Pande Game Reserve in Tanzania (Burgess and Clarke 2000, Doggart 2003, Doggart et al. 2008), and the Udzungwa Scarp Nature Reserve in the Udzungwa Mountains, Tanzania (Rovero et al. 2012, 2015).

Hunting for pelts has been reported in Kenya and Tanzania (Anderson et al. 2007, Rovero et al. 2012).
conservationActions:
Colobus angolensis is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Present in a number of protected areas across its range, including Lomami National Park, Salonga National Park, Virunga National Park and Okapi Wildlife Reserve (DRC), Rwenzori Mountains National Park (Uganda), Nyungwe National Park (Rwanda), Shimba Hills National Reserve (Kenya), and Udzungwa Mountains National Park and Mahale Mountains National Park (Tanzania).

In the Eastern Arc Mountains of Tanzania the species is safe only where there is effective protection, such as in the Udzungwa Mountains National Park.

Colobus Conservation based in Diani, Kenya (the only conservation organisation dedicated to a subspecies of Colobus), promotes the conservation, preservation and protection of C. a. palliatus (and sympatric primate species) and its associated coastal forest habitats.

Colobus angolensis prigoginei is listed as Endangered due to its small range (Mount Kabobo, eastern DRC) and low densities (Plumptre et al. 2008). All other subspecies are listed as Vulnerable.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered because Sclater’s Monkey is estimated to have undergone a population decline exceeding 50% over the past three generations (about 27 years, assuming a generation length of nine years), resulting from a decline in area of occupancy and habitat quality, and high levels of exploitation. This decline is projected to continue into the future, and its rate will probably intensify due to continuing widespread habitat loss and degradation and hunting. Additionally, the species does not occur in any officially gazetted wildlife conservation area. In large part, Sclater’s Monkey persists due to its small size, cryptic nature, adaptability and general non-preferred status among hunters relative to other monkeys. Close population monitoring should take place. However, such monitoring may be hampered by insecurity in the Niger Delta and in other parts of the species’ range and by the lack of an organised national programme in Nigeria focusing on Sclater’s Monkey.
habitat: The original habitat of Sclater’s Monkey is moist tropical lowland forest, but due to severe habitat degradation, this species now persists in remnant secondary, gallery/riparian and freshwater swamp forests. The species is also found in marginal forest and farm-bush in communities where monkeys are regarded as sacred (Oates et al. 1992, Tooze 1995, Baker 2005). Sclater’s Monkey is likely omnivorous, with a diet similar to other members of the C. cephus group: mostly fruits, insects and young foliage (Oates and Baker 2013).
threats: The rapidly growing human population of Nigeria is expected to be the third largest globally by 2050. This growth has been accompanied by widespread environmental degradation and will continue to negatively affect natural habitats. Across Nigeria, land area devoted to agriculture and plantations (crop and grazing lands, floodplain agriculture, irrigation and livestock projects, and tree and forest plantations) increased by nearly 84,000 km² between 1976 and 1995. More than half of the country’s undisturbed lowland moist forest was lost during that same time frame (from 25,951 to 12,114 km²) (Geomatics International et al. 1998). From 1990–2015, net forest loss across Nigeria continued at a rate of 3.5% annually, resulting in a loss of ~4,100 km² each year – more than any other African nation. During this period, Nigeria lost 59.4% of its forested area and 98.7% of its primary forest (FAO 2015). During the latter part of this period, from 2000–2015, the rate of forest loss across Nigeria accelerated (5%) (FAO 2015), and the percent of forest cover declined from 14.4% to 7.7% (World Bank 2017). Conversion of forested areas to farmland is a major contributor to this decline; for the decade ending in 2008, Nigeria converted more land to annual crops than did any other tropical nation (Phalan et al. 2013). The southeastern region of Nigeria, where Sclater’s Monkey occurs, has among the highest human population densities in the country and one of the highest in Africa. As a result, most natural forest across this species’ range has been converted to cultivated land; unregulated logging and activities associated with oil exploration and production have added to the destruction (Oates et al. 1992, Baker and Olubode 2008). Of particular concern for Sclater’s Monkey is severe habitat fragmentation, resulting in a lack of connectivity among existing populations and associated loss of heterozygosity in population isolates. Additionally, the species does not occur in any official wildlife conservation area or have any effective protection from exploitation outside of the very few sites where it is protected by local communities owing to social taboos.
population:
Given widespread habitat loss across this species’ range, many of the remaining populations of Sclater’s Monkey are isolated, and most occur in highly degraded, unprotected forests. This degradation, combined with hunting pressure and lack of official protection, has led to decline of the population. The species’ persistence in southeastern Nigeria can be attributed to the species’ small size, shy nature and adaptability, and preferential hunting of larger-bodied primate taxa (Baker and Olubode 2008). Until the 1990s, Sclater’s Monkey was thought to be very rare, but extensive surveys since then have revealed its presence at a number of formerly unknown sites. In one regional survey, Baker and Olubode (2008) did not encounter any localities of recent extirpation (or sites where local reports indicated that populations of this species had been extirpated even though suitable habitat remains). Nevertheless, encounter rates were low: 0.18 detections per km surveyed.

In the very few sites where it is not hunted, or where hunting is less commonly practised (such as the Niger Delta where some communities rely on fish as their main protein source), this species may fare relatively well compared to larger primates. In the Edumanom Forest Reserve, a comparatively large forest block in the Niger Delta, one study found Sclater’s Monkey to be the most abundant diurnal primate encountered, occurring in an estimated 3.1 groups per km² (Baker et al. 2011). In three village sites where Sclater’s Monkey is protected by social taboos (i.e. monkeys are not killed), populations appear to increase: 1) Lagwa, Imo State (Baker et al. 2014a); 2) Akpugoeze community complex, Enugu State (Baker et al. 2014a, 2018); and 3) Ikot Uso Akpan, Akwa Ibom State (Eniang and Egwali 2011). However, the survival of these populations requires them to adapt to living in heavily deforested, urbanizing environments. Although apparently increasing, these populations are also relatively small: 178 individuals in Ikot Uso Akpan (Eniang and Egwali 2011), 206 individuals in Lagwa (Baker et al. 2014a), and 339 individuals in the Akpugoeze community complex (Baker et al. 2018).
range: This species is endemic to southern Nigeria. It ranges from the eastern Niger Delta in Bayelsa State east to the Cross River, and north to Enugu and Ebonyi States; the most northerly known populations occur in southern Anambra-Enugu States and central Ebonyi State (Baker and Olubode 2008). Sclater’s Monkey was feared extinct until it was sighted southwest of Oguta, Imo State, in 1988 (Oates and Anadu 1989). Additional populations were subsequently discovered in the early to mid-1990s (Oates et al. 1992; Tooze 1995, 1996). In a 2004 regional survey, the species was located in several sites where it had not been previously recorded (Baker 2005, Baker and Olubode 2008). Across its range, this species has generally been recorded in fragmented, degraded forests (Oates et al. 1992, Tooze 1995, Baker and Olubode 2008).
useTrade: Being the smallest diurnal primate across its range (along with Cercopithecus erythrogaster), Sclater’s Monkey has the lowest economic value as bushmeat relative to other diurnal primates. While it is sought after by hunters, some hunters consider the species more difficult to kill due to its size and cryptic nature, and some do not bother hunting Sclater’s Monkey given the lower profit it brings (Baker and Olubode 2008).
conservationActions:
This species is currently listed as Class B under the African Convention and under Appendix II of CITES.

There are no formally protected areas in the range of Sclater’s Monkey. Important conservation measures suggested by Baker (2005) include: 1) elevating the species to Schedule I of the Nigerian Endangered Species Act (this change may not be considered unless the species is elevated to CITES Appendix I); 2) raising awareness about the species and its uniquely Nigerian status through publicity and education; and 3) enhancing protection of key forests, including the Edumanom Forest Reserve in Bayelsa State, Upper Orashi Forest Reserve in Rivers State and the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve in Akwa Ibom State.

Communities where Sclater’s Monkey receives cultural protection (through social taboos) are also very important, although forest cover in these sites has been greatly reduced over time. These include Ikot Uso Akpan and other communities in the Itam region (Akwa Ibom State), Lagwa (Imo State) and the Akpugoeze community complex (Enugu State). In Lagwa and Akpugoeze, previous and existing conservation measures include school-based awareness programmes, stakeholder workshops, documentation and publishing of folklore and oral histories related to the cultural value of monkeys, and population and forest monitoring (Baker 2013; Baker et al. 2009; 2014a,b; 2018). Forest restoration and conservation awareness efforts have also been conducted in Ikot Uso Akpan (Jacob et al. 2013). Development of small-scale ecotourism in these communities should be explored, given how readily monkeys can be observed at these sites.

Other potential areas for enhanced protection are the Niger floodplain and Osomari Forest Reserve (Oates et al. 1992), as well as the Blue River (Azumini, Abia State) and Enyong Creek/Ikpa River (Akwa Ibom State) (Tooze 1995).

rationale:
Although this is a widely distributed species on Sri Lanka, the population is suspected to have declined by more than 50% in the last 40 years (approximately three generations) due to habitat loss at an equal or slightly higher rate. The species is also threatened from persecution as a pest, and minimally from the pet industry

More specifically, according to government data, during the 42-year period (1956-1993) the country lost 50% of its forest cover, and more than 70% if the last 22 years to the present are included. There is a 1:1 relationship between loss of critical habitat and population number of macaques (Dittus 1977). Since 2003 a new threat has emerged: it involves translocating animals considered pests to unsuitable habitats where macaque survival is at risk (Dittus 2012a,b). In addition, there has been a loss of at least 15% of natural habitat in the Northern Dry Zone areas, especially since the end of the war in 2009 and further losses are expected (Mattsson et al. 2012). The large-sized protected areas (as well as unprotected ones) in the dry and arid zones provide suitable ecological habitat in less than 2% of their areas: only along the narrow riverine forests for this water dependent species (Dittus 1977). Therefore, macaque densities in most National Parks and other remaining tracts of the dry zone forests have been estimated to be extremely low: at 0.2–0.5/km² (Eisenberg and Lockhart 1972, McKay 1973, Dittus 1977). Wet zone habitats (M. s. aurifrons) are densely populated by humans and macaques are isolated in fragmented patches and are treated as pests (Nekaris et al. 2013). In the montane areas, M. s. opisthomelas is assessed here as Critically Endangered. This endemic species is threatened also by the fact that it has no legal protection but is managed as a pest species. In human-monkey conflict situations people are at liberty to kill macaque monkeys, and some commercial air-rifle sellers advertise their products with macaques as targets. The overall empirical profile for the species justifies IUCN Endangered status. Notwithstanding, the public perception of macaque numbers countrywide is highly overblown because macaques are often lured out of the forest towards refuse and crops where they are seen easily. Garbage feeding macaque populations can grow exponentially (Dittus 2012, Dittus et al. 2019). These facts, together with macaque-human conflict (Nekaris et al. 2013, Cabral et al. 2018, Dittus et al. 2019), have misled some people to question the species’ overall threatened status, and therefore poses a political challenge for conservation policy and management.
habitat: The species is found in a variety of forest types (Dittus, 1977) at all altitudes up to about 2,100 m (Corbet and Hill 1992). Macaca sinica aurifrons is found in lowland and midland tropical rainforest and wet zone lowland forests, M. s. opisthomelas in montane tropical rainforest, and M. s. sinica in the extensive dry evergreen forest near permanent water. The species is mainly arboreal and terrestrial and diurnal. It is frugivorous, but also consumes flowers, new leaf shoots, tubers, insects, and the occasional small vertebrate. It adapts easily to human foods (Hladik and Hladik, 1972, Dittus, 1977). Its local and wider geographic distributions are limited by the availability of free water; in the dry and arid zones this means that its ecological distribution is far less than suggested by the area of occupancy in red lest assessments (Dittus, 2013).
threats:
The chief threat to this species is habitat loss owing to the encroachment of plantations, and fuel wood collection. Other threats include shooting, snaring and poisoning of the animals, as they are considered to be crop pests (Dittus 2012, Molur et al. 2003).

According to government data, during one 42-year period (1956-1993), the country lost 50% of its forest cover and more than 50% if the last 10 years (1994-2003) are included. Over the last 15 years the rate of decline has remained the same with increasing pressures of habitat modification, forest die back, agriculture, plantations, and settlements. There is a 1:1 relationship between loss of critical habitat and population number. Therefore, the species is reduced numerically minimally by 50% (Dittus 2012, Molur et al. 2003). Much of the original forested habitat of M. s. aurifrons in the southwest rainforest areas has been converted to agriculture, home gardens and plantations. These habitats are inimical to macaque survival because the animals are not tolerated by humans (Molur et al. 2003, Nekaris et al. 2013, Cabral et al. 2018). In addition, 80% of hill country forests were lost to tea plantations during the 19th century. The populatoin of Macaca s. opisthomelas has been reduced by >80% over the last 20 years. This trend is continuing as high elevation natural forests are being converted to agriculture (vegetable plots and dairy pasture) (Molur et al. 2003, Dittus 2013, Gamage et al. 2015, Wickramanayake and Gunatilleke 2002, Wijesundera 2012); the subspecies is assessed as Critically Endangered. The Mahaweli Development Scheme has destroyed much dry-zone forest habitat of M. s. sinica (Molur et al. 2003) and continues to impact dry zone forests (Mattson et al. 2012, Jayasuriya et al. 2006). The protracted civil war in Sri Lanka has had a negative impact on habitat and wildlife in the dry zone (Santiapillai and Wijeyamohan 2003).

The species is also persecuted due to increasing human-wildlife negative interactions throughout the range (Dittus et al. 2019, Cabral et al. 2018, Nekaris et al. 2013). The declines are predicted to continue for another 2-3 decades given the increasing population impacts, development schemes, lack of political will, expanding agriculture and plantations, forest die back, tourism, linear intrusions, and general lack of habitat and wildlife promoting attitudes.
population: The species is widely distributed in Sri Lanka where virtually all populations inhabiting undisturbed natural forest are in decline owed to habitat loss. The three subspecies vary in the degree of old-growth habitat remaining to support population numbers and that of the montane subspecies Macaca sinica opishtomelas is the most threatened. Towns, tourist and temple provides macaques access to human foods and this has developed into concentrations of conspicuous pest macaques at these sites. These sites are highly localized and do not represent macaque population numbers countywide.
range: The species as a whole is endemic to Sri Lanka. The subspecies Macaca sinica sinica is found in the north and east of the island, M. s. aurifrons in the south-west, and M. s. opisthomelas in the central montane region. The species and its subspecies are very fragmented in their distribution, with the wet zone form, M. s. opisthomelas being highly restricted to less than 500 km² in extent of occurrence and less than 100 km² in area of occupancy (Molur et al., 2003; Dittus et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species is in trade, kept as pets in the dry zone.
conservationActions:
Although protected internationally under CITES Appendix II, this is the only endemic species not protected by law in Sri Lanka (Molur et al. 2003).

Macaca sinica sinica occurs in the following protected areas: Menikdene Archaeological Reserve, Ritigala Reserve, Sigiriya Sanctuary, NIFS Popham Arboretum, VRR Sanctuary, Wasgamuwa NP, Angammedilla NP, Hurulu FR , Kaudulla NP,  Minneriya NP, Somawathiya NP,  Flood Plains NP,  Maduru Oya NP, Gal Oya NP, Wilpattu NP, Yala (Ruhunu) NP,  Kumana (Yala East) NP, Lahugala Kitulaga NP, Udawalawe NP (intergrades  with M. s. aurifrons) , Polonnaruwa Nature Sanctuary, Kanthale Naval Sanctuary,  Mihintale Sanctuary, Thangamalai Sanctuary, Kantalai FR, Elahera FR, Baddaragala Sanctuary, Kaludiyapokuna FR,  Ritigala Nature Reserve.

Macaca s. aurifrons is known to occur in numerous protected areas, including: Attidiya-Belanwila Sanctuary, Buddaragala Sanctuary, Dombagaskande Forest Reserve, Kitulgala Sanctuary, Kurulukelle Sanctuary, Menikdena Archaelogical Reserve, Muthurajawela Sanctuary, Remmalakanda Forest Reserve, Rendenigala Sanctuary, Sinharaja Forest Reserve, Udawalawe National Park, Udawattekele Sanctuary,   

Macaca s. opisthomelas occurs in the Peak Wilderness Area (high elevations) and the Hakgala Strict Natural Reserve, and  marginal areas of the Horton Plains National Park.

Although listed internationally under CITES Appendix II, this is the only endemic species not protected by law within Sri Lanka (Flora and Fauna Protection [Amendment] Act, no. 22 of 2009) where the species is generally considered a  pest. Recent red list reviews by the Sri Lankan government (independently of the IUCN) assess the macaque species’ status as “Least Concern”; the subspecies were not evaluated (MOE, 2012). With respect to Sri Lankan primates, different approaches to red list assessment have led to conflicting conclusions about taxon status (Dittus 2013).

The conservation of the Toque Macaque should be improved by upgrading this species to protected status in Sri Lankan wildlife ordinances.  Human-monkey conflict would be greatly reduced by effective management of food refuse discarded by humans in a manner that prevents macaques, langurs and other wildlife from gaining access to it. Crop raiding by monkeys can be reduced by engaging professionally trained crop guardians. Human-macaque conflict reduction should be addressed as one component of a more general human-wildlife conflict challenge, and translocation of any wild animals considered as pests (macaques, purple-faced langurs, elephants) should be outlawed for the welfare of animals and humans alike (Dittus 2012 a,b; Dittus et al. 2019; Fernando et al. 2012).

rationale: Cercocebus galeritus is listed as Critically Endangered. This species is endemic to forests along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River. This species lives in about 27 distinct, small, forests, some of which are isolated. In 1994, the area occupied by this species was less 26 km² and the population was ca 1,000–1,200 individuals. Current population is estimated at ca 1,000 individuals. Population reduction is expected to continue, based on a continuing decline in its area of occupancy and extent of occurrence, as a result of the current high rate of habitat degradation, fragmentation and loss due to unsustainable exploitation of forest, woodland, and bushland by people. A future population reduction exceeding 80% over three generations (33 years) is predicted, given the rate of decline in forest cover levels reached in recent years. This is especially likely if the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) is officially annulled, an action now being considered by national authorities. The entire population lies in a politically insecure area over which there is a low level of conservation activity, and much unplanned, unregulated, and unsustainable exploitation of natural resources.
habitat: Cercocebus galeritus is restricted to flood-plain forest, riverine gallery forest, and the adjacent woodland and bushland (Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013). Abundance is highly correlated with the spatial characteristics of the forests (Wahungu et al. 2005). It is a semi-terrestrial monkey that can travel up to 1 km through non-forested habitat between forest patches (Wieczkowski 2010). Mean group size is ca 27 individuals (range: 6–62; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013). Cercocebus galeritus is frugivorous and forages predominantly on the ground and up to 2 m above the ground (Homewood 1978). It feeds on seeds, fruits, stems, leaves, insects and fungi (Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013).
threats:
Cercocebus galeritus has declined as a result of several causes including: (a) drastic changes in vegetation due to dam construction, irrigation projects and water diversion, which affect both the water table and the frequency and severity of flooding which, in turn, affect the extent and quality of this species’ forest habitat; (b) forest clearance for agriculture; (c) fires that destroy forests; (d) habitat degradation due to livestock and (e) the unsustainable collection of wood and other forest products; (f) selective felling of fig trees for canoes; (g) exploitation of one of the species’ top food plants, Phoenix reclinata; and (h) corruption, inter-ethnic violence and insecurity. There is also percution of C. galeritus as a crop pest and this is expected to increase as natural foods become less available due to habitat loss (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000, de Jong and Butynski 2012, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013, Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016, Butynski and de Jong 2019). Because all remaining forests inhabited by C. galeritus are small and seriously threatened, the long-term survival of the species is in question.

There has been considerable alteration of river flow volume and the flood cycle by five hydroelectric power dams up-river (Butynski 1995). A sixth dam, the High Grand Falls Dam, is under construction (Hamerlynck et al. 2012; Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016). The High Grand Falls Dam, the second largest dam in Africa, will be accompanied by large-scale irrigation schemes and water transfer to the ‘Lamu Port and Lamu Southern Sudan-Ethiopia Transport Corridor’. The establishment of this dam is expected to have additional negative impacts on the forests of the Lower Tana River and, therefore, on C. galeritus.

One special concern is the rapidly growing human population in the region. Another is the possible annulment of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR; 169 km²), which the High Court of Kenya ordered in January 2007. According to the Kenya Wildlife Act 2013, Section 37, change of boundaries or revocation of a National Reserve can only be published by the Cabinet Secretary and approved by Parliament. Change or revocation can only be recommended if they do not endanger any species or critical habitat. As such, it seems unlikely that annulment will occur despite the court ruling in 2007.

About 56% of C. galeritus occur in TRPNR. Even with the continued existence of the TRPNR the long-term survival of C. galeritus is not certain as the high level of insecurity and inadequate law enforcement in the region is expected to continue, as is the growth in the human population (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013, Butynski and de Jong 2019).
population: Cercocebus galeritus is often relatively common where present (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013). In 1994, population density was ca 0.45 individuals per ha of occupied forest habitat (Butynski and Mwangi 1994). Genetic analyses show that the effective population size is <100 individuals (Mbora and McPeek 2015). The global population is roughly 1,000 individuals.
range:
Cercocebus galeritus is endemic to a stretch of flood-plain forests along the lower Tana River, northern coastal Kenya, from Nkanjonja in the north to Hewani in the south, with an altitudinal range of 20–40 m asl. This species lives in about 27 distinct, small (1–500 ha) forests, some of which are isolated. The area over which this species lives is less than 26 km² (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013).

Cercocebus galeritus is broadly sympatric with Piliocolobus rufomitratus, Cercopithecus mitis albotorquatus, Paragalago cocos, Otolemur garnettii lasiotis, and narrowly sympatric on forest edge with Papio cynocephalus ibeanus, Chlorocebus pygerythrus hilgerti, and Galago senegalensis braccatus (De Jong and Butynski 2009, 2012; Butynski and De Jong 2019).
useTrade: There is some hunting of Cercocebus galeritus as a crop pest and this is expected to increase as natural foods become less available due to habitat loss (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; de Jong and Butynski 2012; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013; Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016; Butynski and de Jong 2018).
conservationActions:
Cercocebus galeritus is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class A of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Given the current poor management of the TRPNR, the continued clearing of forest and settlement of people within the TRPNR, and the low level of conservation activity in the region, the long-term survival of C. galeritus seems bleak. A small number of C. galeritus may still be present in the Tana River Delta. This delta became a Ramsar Site in 2012. Otherwise, the Tana River Delta has no protected area status.

Ndera Community Conservancy, established in 2010 with the help of the Northern Rangeland Trust (www.nrt-kenya.org), aims to conserve 150 km² of habitat along the lower Tana River  and to improve the viability of forest patches within and outside the TRPNR (Mbora and Allen 2011, J. King pers. obs. 2016). The Ndera Community Conservancy provides an opportunity for improved conservation of those forests upon which C. galeritus depends.

Stringent habitat protection is required. The Mchelelo Research Station in the TRPNR should be rehabilitated and re-established.

rationale: Plecturocebus ornatus is listed as Vulnerable in light of a continued decline inferred from more than a 30% loss of habitat in the past three generations (24 years), which is expected to continue at the same rate for the next three generations, due to a decline in area of occupancy and habitat quality as a consequence of deforestation caused by African palm oil expansion, petrol exploration and exploitation, illicit crops and expanding human settlements (Carretero-Pinzón 2013).
habitat:
Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (Heymann pers. comm., 2008) and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000, Wallace pers. comm.). Members of the Plecturocebus moloch and Plecturocebus cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (Roosmalen et al. 2002). Plecturocebus ornatus typically occurs in lowland tropical forests (canopy 15-20 m) (Defler 2010) and disturbed habitats (Mason 1968). A recent research in San Martin area, in 100 forest fragments, found P. ornatus groups in fragments of gallery forest, lowland rainforest and Mauritia flexuosa swamps (Carretero-Pinzón and Defler, in prep).

The ecology of this species has been studied in the department of Meta by Mason (1965, 1966, 1966, 1968, and 1971) and Robinson (1977, 1979, 1979, 1981, and 1982). Polanco (1992) and Porras (2000) studied a population near the Duda River.
threats: This species occurs in an area subject to intense human colonization that has been subject to widespread habitat destruction and fragmentation. As mentioned by Carretero-Pinzón (2013) a reduction of 35% of their distribution area has occurred in the last decade. This habitat loss and fragmentation has been produced by cattle ranching, palm oil plantation extensions and petrol exploration and exploitation (Wagner et al. 2009, Carretero-Pinzón 2013).
population:
Robinson (1977) recorded a population density of five individuals/ km². Wagner et al. (2009) found higher densities (192.2 ind/ km2) in small fragments, while Carretero-Pinzón (2013) found lower densities (57.94 ind/ km2 and 1.073 ind/ km2) for range of fragments between 16 ha and 1,050 ha.

Carretero-Pinzón (2013) reported a 35% reduction of distribution area for this species between 2003 and 2013 caused by habitat loss and fragmentation. Habitat loss is continuing. As a result, it is suspected that the population has suffered a reduction of at least 30% over the last 24 years (three generations), and that this reduction is likely to continue over the next 24 years.
range: This species occurs in eastern Colombia, in the department of Cundinamarca (Medina) north as far as the lower Río Upía/ Río Meta, south into the department of Meta, along the base of the Cordillera Oriental and the Sierra de la Macarena to the Río Guayabero/ upper Río Guaviare. It is the only member of the cupreus and moloch group occurring north of the Rios Amazonas/ Solimões/ Napo axis, in the upper Río Orinoco basin and is separated from the nearest other member of the cupreus group (Plecturocebus discolor) in the south by at least 350 km (Roosmalen et al. 2002). Eastern limits are poorly known but probably extend beyond Metica River (Defler 2010).
conservationActions: This species occurs in La Macarena National Park and Tinigua National Park. Although some populations are found within protected areas, guerilla activity makes it difficult to monitor these areas (T. Defler pers comm.).It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Tarsius pumulus is assessed as Endangered because it has a small area of occupancy (175 km²) and that the species is known from only two isolated locations. In addition, the species is likely undergoing a decline in quality of habitat from localised, small scale exploitation of the habitat due to expanding human settlements.
habitat:
Tarsius pumilus is among the least known primates in existence. It has only recently (August 2008) been rediscovered in the wild, captured, radio collared, photographed, and filmed. Morphological analysis of museum specimens indicates adaptations for life in colder, montane cloud forests (Musser and Dagosto 1987). Moss forests are characteristic of the presumed habitat.

Hilly and mountainous regions in elevations between 1,800–2,200 m with trees covered in liverworts and mosses. Feeds on live animal prey as insects and lizards. Nocturnal and arboreal in habit.
threats: Its distribution is in all likelihood restricted to isolated mountain tops; it is known to occur in only two isolated locations. One threat to these habitats is the encroachment of human populations into montane regions to satisfy the needs of a growing human population. The destruction of montane forests in more densely populated south Sulawesi indicates that this fate may well be in store for Central Sulawesi's montane forests as the human population expands. Some areas of Central Sulawesi near known Tarsius pumilus sites are conflict zones, where factional fighting has seen the dislocation of large human populations that are then resettled in refugee camps. One such site lies along the main route to the Rorekatimbu capture locality.
population: The species is thought to live in extremely low densities due to low trapping rate.
range: This species occurs in southern and central Sulawesi, Indonesia and is currently only known to be present in two locations: Mt. Nokilalaki and Mt. Rantemario. The first specimen of Tarsius pumilus was collected in 1916 at 1,800 m from Rano Rano, in the mountains between Palu and Poso and the Latimojong Mts The second specimen, collected in 1930, came from 2,200 m on Mount Rantemario in South Sulawesi. A third specimen, which was found dead in a rat trap in May 2000, came from 2,200 m on the flank of Mount Rorekatimbu. The first live sighting was in 2008 and the first nearly after 80 years, when scientists captured and released three individuals and observed one other individual high up in the canopy. It is important to find other locations of presence in its presumed distribution to inform its conservation status assessment. The extent of occurrence is estimated at 5,231 km².
useTrade: Use of this species is not known.
conservationActions: It is listed on CITES Appendix II. The species is known to occur in at least one protected area (Lore Lindu National Park), although the form likely receives some protection on Mount Rantemario (M. Shekelle pers. comm.). Protected in Lore Lindu National Park and somewhat protected in Mount RanteMario.

rationale: Kinixys homeana is experiencing a very serious decline over much of its range, due mainly to extensive habitat loss, intensive harvesting for subsistence and traditional medicine ("ju-ju"), and exploitation for the international pet trade, leading to markedly decreased tortoise densities in severely decreased remaining habitat. At many sites, tortoise populations are impacted by two or three of the above concurrent threats, causing catastrophic population declines. It is more than likely that these threats will continue to grow in the next several years, due to continuing rates of deforestation, human population density and growth, and industrial development in some crucial areas (e.g., southern Nigeria, southern Cote d’Ivoire). Although there are no specific data on the decline of global populations of K. homeana, we can extrapolate global population declines using data from Nigeria as a benchmark. Assuming that: 1) the density of tortoises has remained constant in remaining suitable habitats (however, this is unlikely in view of hunting pressures), 2) local hunting pressures have remained constant over the years (also unlikely in view of human population growth from about 35 million in 1959 to approximately 120 million in 2001), and 3) that the suitable habitat for K. homeana has declined by at least 90% in the last 45 years based on known habitat loss, then it can be estimated that in 1960 there were at least 5,000,000 tortoises in Nigeria compared to an estimate of about 500,000 today. Using these estimates (i.e., a ca. 90% decline in suitable habitat in the past ca. 45 years or about three tortoise generations, translating to a decline of roughly 30% per generation of ca. 15 years), K. homeana can be classified as Critically Endangered according to IUCN criteria CR A2bcd. Assuming that rates of deforestation and human population growth will continue into the future, we can also estimate that the ongoing population reductions of K. homeana would be 30% for each of the past two generation times (30 years) and 30% for the future one generation time of 15 yrs, indicating that the species can also be assessed as CR A4bcd. As noted, this assessment is specific for Nigeria, not range-wide, but there is no indication that Nigeria represents an exceptional case of decline (apart from its high human population size), but more of a best-studied case and indicative for most of the region. Ghana and Togo have among of the highest deforestation rates in Africa, with the former, for instance, at 2% (135,000 ha) loss per year. Thus, approximately 1,931,000 ha (26%) of K. homeana habitat was lost between 1990 and 2005. Recent field searches indicate populations in Ghana have suffered significant loss or have been extirpated, and the same has also occurred in Togo and Cote d’Ivoire. Similar extrapolations can be performed for other range countries as well, and all these calculations lead to the conclusion that: 1) population declines have been very rapid for K. homeana, and 2) there is no reason to predict that this trend will be reversed or slowed. Kinixys homeana was previously assessed as Data Deficient on the Red List in 1996 and reassessed as Vulnerable in 2006.
habitat:
Kinixys homeana is a small to medium-sized forest tortoise (with a carapace length of up to about 23 cm), with an omnivorous diet and specialized habitat-selection for rainforest and swamp forest patches. It is diurnal or crepuscular, and particularly active above-ground after rains, during the wet season.

The species prefers moist forests that provide closed canopy and shady microhabitats (Luiselli 2005; Luiselli and Diagne 2013; Mifsud and Stapleton 2014), however it has also been associated with streams and swampy areas (Maran and Serpol 2006; Branch 2007). According to some sources, it generally inhabits forests that are drier than those inhabited by the similar species, K. erosa (Broadley 1989; Ernst and Barbour 1989; Lawson 1993, 2006), but in Cameroon, Cote d’Ivoire and Nigeria the opposite has also been observed (Chirio and LeBreton 2007, Luiselli and Diagne 2013). In most sites, this species occurs syntopically with K. erosa (for instance, in Liberia, Cote d’Ivoire, Nigeria and Togo), and in the Togo hills bordering Ghana and in a few sites in the Niger Delta also with K. nogueyi (Segniagbeto et al. 2014). Overlap in range between these species may be a limiting factor in habitat occupancy due to interspecific competition for local resources (Luiselli 2003b). Research in the River Niger Delta in southern Nigeria has shown populations of K. homeana to be habitat specialists associated with mature secondary forests around mangroves and mature secondary swamp forests (Luiselli et al. 2000). In all of this area, primary forests are totally extirpated, and hence these tortoises inhabit the closest and more mature secondary forests. In general, many populations of this species are severely fragmented and isolated inside remnant patches of holy forests (Akani, Eniang, Luiselli, Ebere, Petrozzi, unpubl. data). Lawson (2000, 2006) found this species to be sympatric with K. erosa in neighboring Cameroon, with adult specimens of both sexes of both species with overlapping home ranges. Multiple specimens of both species have been observed feeding on ephemeral mushrooms at the same time (Lawson, unpubl. data). Within the eastern region of the Niger Delta, Luiselli (2003a) demonstrated the type of treatment K. homeana receives by local communities may play a large role in habitat selection. In communities that treat K. homeana as a holy animal, individuals can be found in diverse habitats such as dense brush, sparse brush, swamps, and plantations. In contrast, communities where K. homeana is actively hunted, observations are limited to dense brushy areas. 

The species has an omnivorous diet that includes plant matter, seeds, fungi, worms, snails, slugs, and various arthropods that can vary slightly between habitat type (Luiselli 2006b). It may forage on small amphibians, fish, and carrion (Branch 2007) and has a more carnivorous diet than other testudinids (Luiselli 2006c) and forages for food by following olfactory paths with straight, darting jabs of its head (Eglis 1962). In captivity, K. homeana relishes plantain and banana tree piths (E. Eniang pers. obs.).

Kinixys homeana is primarily more active during the wet season and is known to use floods as a way to disperse by floating rather than swimming. In areas where seasonal flooding occurs, this type of movement is common (Luiselli et al. 2016 and unpubl. obs.). At least occasionally, the species has been observed to mate in water bodies (Luiselli, Akani and Eniang, unpubl. data). Field studies that investigated homing patterns in Cameroon (Lawson 2006) and Nigeria (Luiselli et al. unpubl. data) tracked individuals through habitats that differed regionally and environmentally. Data from these studies show similar results in that males tend to be highly territorial, driving out other males from home ranges that may exceed 0.5 sq. km. These results indicate that the density of K. homeana is likely to be low even in areas with highly suitable habitat. 

Luiselli and Akani (upubl. data) report mating events in the wild from mid-March to the end of May, and also in September, in southern Nigeria. Females oviposit one to two times per year, typically between December and January during the dry season (Blackwell 1968; George 1994). Eggs are brittle, oval to nearly spherical, and measure approximately 46 x 35 mm (Branch 2007). Nests contain 2–4 eggs and are typically deposited in forest litter and excavated burrows (Blackwell 1968). In captivity clutches of as many as six eggs have been reported (Mifsud and Thompson, unpubl. data). Incubation time in the wild is unknown; however, in captivity eggs will hatch 89–102 days after being incubated at 28–30°C (Koehler 1997). It is suspected that this species has temperature-dependent sex determination (D. Mifsud pers. comm.). Hatchlings generally measure about 42–47 mm CL (Branch 2007) but are known to reach up to 50 mm CL (Farkas and Satorhelyi 2006). Based on experiences in captivity and by analogy with other forest tortoises (e.g., Indotestudo spp.), generation time for the species is estimated as 15 yrs, based on estimated maturity at 10 yrs and estimated longevity (in captivity) of 60 yrs.

The most detailed study on the habitat preferences of K. homeana has been done in southern Nigeria. At a landscape scale, a statistical study (based on logistic regression of presence/absence data) revealed that Nigerian populations of K. homeana are habitat specialists, being linked to zones of secondary dry forest around mangroves and in zones with secondary swamp-forest (Luiselli et al. 2000). Considering that in the Delta states these habitat types have declined dramatically during the last decades, falling from 2% of state area in 1976–78 to only 0.2% in 1993–95 (Geomatics 1996) due primarily to petrochemical expansion, it may be inferred that habitat loss represents a very serious reason of decline for these tortoises at a global scale. This supposition is reinforced by evidence that K. homeana needs closed forest canopy and shady microhabitats to avoid overheating, and shows behavioural thermoregulation in its avoidance of overheating (Luiselli 2005), i.e., allowing only short periods of exposure to the sun during movements between sunlit and shaded areas (Hailey and Coulson 1998, Luiselli 2005). Another potential limitation factor of habitat occupancy by K. homeana may be a potential for interspecific competition for food with the closely related K. erosa, which exhibits a wide overlap in terms of spatial use (Luiselli 2003b).

At a local scale, Luiselli (2003a) demonstrated that the type of attitude of human communities towards tortoises may have very serious consequences on the habitat preferences of these animals, so that any generalization can be difficult. Luiselli (2003a) studied tortoise population ecology at six study areas with similar habitat characteristics in the eastern axis of the Niger Delta. In three areas, the tortoises had been worshipped by local communities for a long time as holy animals, whereas in three other areas they were actively hunted for subsistence. The habitat use by tortoises varied depending on the type of treatment by the indigenous people (hunting vs. veneration): in the veneration areas the tortoises were frequently found in disparate habitats (i.e., dense dry bush, sparse dry bush, riparian vegetation, swamps, and plantations; Luiselli 2003a). In the hunting areas the tortoises were found almost exclusively inside dense bush, and always avoided plantations. It seems likely that the different habitat usage reflects extirpation from easier hunting areas (Luiselli 2003a). This study may have important global consequences for this species' status, because it demonstrates that wherever they are hunted for subsistence (which is a common occurrence in West and Central Africa, e.g., see Fa et al. 2000, Lawson 2000, Fa and Garcia Juste 2001, Luiselli et al. 2003), the habitat in which they are still found is just a fraction of the potential habitat. They are limited to forest patches with very dense vegetation where access for human hunters is difficult. Forest habitat loss is an enormous problem in West Africa because of the rate of destruction (Oates 1999), and concomitant with this, human population growth and increasing hunting pressure (e.g., Luiselli 2003a,c; Luiselli et al. 2003) means that the long-term viability of these tortoises is at very high risk.
threats:
Populations of Kinixys homeana are heavily declining throughout much of its range likely due to multiple factors including habitat loss and exploitation by local people for consumption as well as commercial collection for urban bushmeat markets and the international pet trade (Luiselli and Diagne 2013; Mifsud and Stapleton 2014). According to Luiselli et al. (2021), the estimated percentage involvement of threats driving this tortoise toward extinction is 50% habitat loss, 40% local consumption as bushmeat, and 10% exploitation for the international pet trade.

Habitat loss is the main threat for this species. Deforestation is occurring rapidly in Africa for profitable resources as well as conversion to agriculture and industrial expansion. Southern Nigeria has experienced rampant deforestation due to development of large areas for oil and natural gas production as well as unplanned urbanization in the last 25 years following creation of Akwa Ibom state in 1987. Ghana has one of the highest deforestation rates in Africa at 2% (135,000 hectares) loss per year, and approximately 1,931,000 hectares (26%) of K. homeana habitat was lost between 1990 and 2005 for gold mining, rubber plantations, and palm oil plantations (UNEP 2008). These destructive activities present a significant threat for the loss of high quality habitat. Clearance of forest for cultivation is also considered a cause of decline for K. homeana in Cameroon (e.g., around Nfainchang; Lawson 1993). In Nigeria, the species has disappeared due to slash-and-burn agricultural practices, persisting only in non-burnt mature forest sites (Akani et al. 2018). Although we do not have quantitative data for other countries it is obvious that the same is happening almost everywhere in the range of this tortoise, since in all these countries human population density is growing, forest loss is rapid, and hunting for subsistence is rampant (e.g., see discussion in Oates 1999).

A recent dangerous trend currently devastating habitats and decimating tortoise and other wildlife species are Fulani cattle herders from the north who have migrated into Akwa Ibom and Cross River states in the hundreds to occupy a majority of the remnant riparian and wetlands forests ecosystems (the last known habitats for tortoises) to carry on indiscriminate cattle grazing with its attendant yearly cultural bush burning to encourage new grass growth, thereby destroying tortoise eggs and live animals, and turning the areas into savannas. Akwa Ibom state has become the centre of cattle trade and consumption following a new culture in which families pride and eulogize themselves for how many cattle are slaughtered during family funeral ceremonies. With this development, more and more cattle herders migrate down and carry on with grazing without restraint. E. Eniang (pers. comm.) predicts that unless protected areas are created and managed effectively in Akwa Ibom state, K. homeana and other tortoises will be locally extirpated within the next 25 years,

Hunting by locals who have no other means is another crucial factor in tortoise population declines (Lawson 2000, Luiselli 2003c). Kinixys are sold in markets throughout Africa and exported internationally for pet trade, consumption, and medicinal purposes (Luiselli 2003b). Surveys of bushmeat and fetish markets in the Niger Delta, Cote d’Ivoire, Benin, Ghana, and Togo conducted by Luiselli et al. (2008, 2013) over an extended period of time revealed significant declines in the number of K. homeana and other Kinixys tortoises for sale, indicating that the numbers of wild individuals are in serious decline. If we consider the proportion of traded quantity decrease in the bushmeat markets over a 10 yr period as a proxy for equivalent population decreases in the wild, it can be calculated that more than 90% of adult tortoises were extirpated from the Niger Delta territory during this time. Hunters also agreed that their numbers decreased considerably in the Nigerian forests (Luiselli et al. 2013). For instance, this species is now very rare even inside mature forests in protected areas of Nigeria, where they still occur in narrow portions of territory (Luiselli et al. 2016). The same clear declining trend was also reported by local hunters in Togo that have collected these tortoises for the international pet trade for the past 30 yrs (Luiselli, Petrozzi, and Segniagbeto, unpubl. data). Most of these tortoises are removed during the wet season, during snail and mushroom gathering (Luiselli et al. 2019; Luiselli, Akani and Eniang, unpubl. data). Snail hunters in Ghana collect tortoises for the international pet trade but have reported increased difficulty finding individuals, and smaller sizes of those that are found (Allman and Agyekumhene, unpubl. data).

The impact of collection/hunting/poaching and/or depredation on annual survival rates of Kinixys species is probably significant. A long-term (14 yrs) demographic study of three Kinixys species (K. homeana, K. erosa, and K. nogueyi) performed in southern Nigeria (Cayuela et al. 2019) suggested that the relationship between mortality rate and age was positive and linear, claiming gradually increasing annual mortality rates over their lifetimes. Mean annual survival probability in a very small study plot (0.24 sq. km) was calculated as 0.70 (95% Confidence Interval 0.62–0.77), with survival probability of 0.95 at 9 years, 0.50 at 12 years, 0.25 at 13 years, and < 0.05 at 16 years. The maximum survival of members of the resident population (based on capture-mark-recapture studies) was about 17 years, but it excluded transient animals (defined as single capture individuals) and did not account for potentially poached or depredated individuals from the population. The low maximum detected age, together with the absence of older and larger individuals, indicated population declines and extirpation of the cohort of larger individuals, likely due to a combination of transience and exploitation loss. Additionally, a long-term (12 yrs) demographic study of a population of K. spekii in a larger study area in Zimbabwe (2 sq. km), yielded similar an annual survival probability of 0.74 and maximum detected survival of about 16 years (Coulson and Hailey 2001), with losses in that population due largely to natural predation as well as possible transience.

Export quotas under CITES in 2000 revealed thousands of K. homeana that were either wild-caught or allegedly ranched being sold in international markets (Anonymous 2000), with about 86,000 total exports documented by CITES from 1990 through 2019 (https://trade.cites.org/). The designation "ranched" is of dubious validity given enforcement of wildlife laws and regulations throughout West and Central Africa, and we are unaware of any legitimate ranching operations in the region. Research has shown that K. homeana can be found in more diverse, open habitats in regions where the tortoise is not actively hunted compared to areas of active hunting where they occupy dense brushy areas that are hard for humans to reach. It is likely that the species has been extirpated from areas where they are easily captured. Luiselli (2003a) documented that in areas where K. homeana is threatened by interaction with local human communities, it occupies only a small portion of available suitable habitat.
population:
According to a suite of field surveys, long-term capture-mark-recapture studies on single populations, examination of bushmeat markets, and interviews with local hunters and sellers, in Cote d’Ivoire, Ghana, Togo, Nigeria, and Cameroon, there is clear evidence that the wild populations of Kinixys homeana are heavily declining and collapsing throughout the species’ range, with cases of extirpation even inside protected areas (Luiselli et al. 2006; Branch 2007; Chirio and LeBreton 2007; Luiselli and Diagne 2013; Mifsud and Stapleton 2014). 

Research by Luiselli (2003a) provided insight into what the rough density of K. homeana may be under natural conditions. After 20 days of field work in southern Nigeria, data showed an average density of 1.4 tortoises/ha at six locations. Density ranged from 0.15 to 0.9 tortoises/ha in harvested areas and from 1.65 to 2.85 tortoises/ha in areas where the species is worshipped. Using a different approach (DISTANCE analysis on transect data), Luiselli et al. (2008) determined the mean density varied between 0.403 tortoises/ha and 1.480 tortoises/ha. Lawson (2000, 2006) extrapolated densities as low as 0.03 tortoises/ha for K. homeana and K. erosa combined in Cameroon, and annual exploitation rates as high as 0.007 tortoises/ha. 

In Nigeria, where the human population density is expanding rapidly (about 125 million people in 2000 and almost 200 million in 2019) and where the remnant proportion of forests is only about 1% of that found in the 1950s (Geomatics 1996), it is almost certain that the current tortoise range is far less than 10% of its former range; we suggest that a more appropriate estimate of the current range of K. homeana in Nigeria is <5% of that in 1992 (Luiselli and Akani, unpubl. data). A current occupation of <5% of the 1992 range would translate to an assessment, for the Nigerian populations, as Critically Endangered under criteria A2c. It has not been reported anywhere that the species survives significantly better in other countries (Luiselli and Diagne 2013); instead, surveys in Cote d’Ivoire (2020) revealed that the species is (almost certainly) extirpated also from coastal forest sites where it was relatively common in 2010–2012. Based on our calculations, the status of K. homeana is clearly becoming increasingly threatened due to the considerable extent of habitat loss in addition to high levels of subsistence hunting. Although few fieldwork-based data on the current area of occupancy (AOO) exist outside of Nigeria for K. homeana, we estimate it as representing no more than ca. 10% of the presumed historic indigenous range, based on region-wide loss and degradation of appropriate habitat, yielding an estimate of AOO of ca. 43,500 km².

Interviews of local hunters selling tortoises in bushmeat markets have also reported a decline (Luiselli et al. 2013). Population sizes of K. homeana are likely markedly reduced in areas where these tortoises are actively hunted. In this regard, it has been recently demonstrated that these tortoises have nearly disappeared from the local bushmeat trade in nine markets of southern Nigeria, thus possibly indicating commercial extinction of wild populations at the local level (Luiselli et al. 2013). The Ebola virus outbreak in Nigeria in 2014 led to a fairly short-term ban on the sale of many mammal species there, while allowing continued trade in tortoises, notably Kinixys spp.; by the time mammal trade returned to pre-Ebola levels, tortoise availability in these markets had decreased markedly (Funk et al. in press), suggesting further depletion of regional subpopulations. Many subpopulations are isolated, and in general, the range of this species is severely fragmented (for instance, the subpopulations inhabiting the central block of the River Niger forests are now totally isolated from those inhabiting the Cross River forests, with a few isolated and very small subpopulations still remaining in holy forests, totally surrounded by unsuitable habitats of the Akwa-Ibom State (Luiselli et al. unpubl. data).  

In the Niger Delta of southern Nigeria, during 1995–2002, we (Luiselli et al., unpubl. data) radio-tracked 33 adults (20 males and 13 females) for 40 continuous days, and measured mean ”area of activity” (quantified via minimum convex polygon) of 0.37 km² for males and 0.24 km² for females, with some specimens (especially males) exhibiting “areas of activity” as large as 0.46 km². Lawson (2000) also stated that, in western Cameroon, male home range may exceed 0.5 km²; his data were very similar to our own despite the different study regions and environmental conditions. Moreover, both in Nigeria (Luiselli et al. unpubl. data) and in Cameroon (Lawson 2000), male tortoises are highly territorial, and usually drive other males away from their core home ranges. Thus, the density of these tortoises is low in most places, even in highly suitable environments. Luiselli (2003a) presented some data on population structure and abundance of K. homeana that can be useful for calculating a rough density of these tortoises under natural conditions. During 20 consecutive field days of research in southern Nigeria (10 days in the wet season and 10 days in the dry season, from February 2001 to January 2002) ten people independently searching a 20 ha area found an average density of 1.4 tortoises/ha at six localities. The density ranged from 0.15 to 0.9 tortoises/ha in harvest areas, and from 1.65 to 2.85 tortoises/ha in veneration areas (Luiselli 2003a).

Kinixys homeana is known to inhabit similar habitats across its entire range, and data from separate regions (Cameroon and Nigeria) showed a clear similarity also in ”areas of activity” and territoriality. Hence we may use the above population density of approximately 1.4 individuals/ha for K. homeana in Nigeria to extrapolate estimates for the whole species range. Calculating population size from the population density estimates (Luiselli 2003a), we expect approximately 140 tortoises in an area of 1 km², which would give a figure of about 1,300,900 tortoises in all of Nigeria according to the most optimistic view (i.e., assuming that in 50% of the occupied sites there is veneration, and no hunting pressure). However, since our data show that veneration occurs in less than 1% of the occupied sites, the total tortoise population figure would be much lower. With an average density (calculated from Luiselli 2003a for harvest areas) of 0.53 individuals/ha this gives 53.33 tortoises/km², and about 500,000 tortoises in all of Nigeria. This latter figure is probably a much more accurate population estimate. If we apply the above reasoning to the whole of this species’ range, we calculate an estimated total population size for K. homeana of at best 4,205,000 tortoises, but probably much less given the current fragmentation and exploitation of the forested patches in West Africa. In this regard, it is noteworthy that the great majority of K. homeana wild populations do occur in flat areas and lowlands, where habitat exploitation is easy and rampant all throughout West Africa. 

Lawson (2000) studied the harvest rates of K. homeana in three protected areas of Cameroon (Korup National Park, Banyang-Mbo Sanctuary, and Nta-Ali Reserve), where poaching on these reptiles was still rampant despite legal protection. He estimated an overall mean annual harvest rate of 0.3 animals/km² in these areas with good habitat conditions and relatively low human density. At that time, if 100% of the species’ range was effectively protected (no poaching) and under relatively low human density, and extrapolating harvest data by Lawson (2000), the expected annual harvest rate would have been 236,532 tortoises, i.e., 5.6% of the total surviving tortoise population. However, the per cent of protected territory is less than 3% of the species’ range, there are mostly no controls against poaching in many protected areas, and the human population density is much higher in several regions of the species’ range than in the three protected areas of Cameroon studied by Lawson (2000), and hence we may conclude that the annual harvest rate is certainly much higher than the calculated 5.6%, but not specifically quantifiable on the basis of current data. Also acknowledging the theoretical limits of our calculations, which are estimates, it is still very likely that the free-ranging populations of this species cannot sustain the current pressure (combination of continuing habitat loss and hunting) for more than 2–3 generations, with each generation being about 15 years.

Field searches and community surveys have been conducted routinely at two sites in Ghana since 2010 (Allman and Agyekumhene, unpubl. data). Snail hunters started collecting K. homeana because of an increase in demand for pet trade export. The snail hunters indicated a previous harvest rate of 15 tortoises per day within Pra Suhein Forest Reserve, but this had decreased to 2–3 small individuals per day by 2017, and often they did not find any at all. These animals were collected for the sole purpose of export into the pet trade. Field searches indicated that tortoise density was three per hectare in 2012, but this had decreased to 1.4 per hectare by 2017 (Allman and Agyekumhene, unpubl. data). 

Country-specific population data are provided below:

Liberia - No recent survey on the distribution of this species in Liberia has been published; however, Luiselli and Fa (unpubl. data) have examined bushmeat markets and surveyed forest patches of this country in 2018. Several specimens (>50) were found by their research staff in the bushmeat markets of Monrovia, Buchanan, and Gbarnga during July 2000. According to the sellers, the tortoises were captured in the nearby surroundings. They also captured (and marked) 14 specimens in the coastal forest around Greenville, in July 2002, during a period of 8 consecutive days of research (a total of 68 man-hours spent in the field). Kinixys homeana was reported by villagers at that time to be locally common (e.g., around Gbarnga), and the pilot surveys in Greenville established an average sighting frequency of 1.75 tortoises/day by the team, which is intermediate between those observed in southern Nigeria in 1) a harvest area (0.84 tortoises/day) and 2) a non-harvest area (2.98 tortoises/day) (Luiselli 2003a). Based on interviews with local hunters and on our preliminary data, we believe that K. homeana is still widespread in Liberia, although likely declining due to over-exploitation by people. In particular, the civil war which has raged throughout Liberia in recent years, followed by the Ebola crisis in 2014–2015, has had serious consequences for several populations of this species. Kinixys homeana became a common food item for people displaced into forests or bushlands to escape the fighting. Indeed, several interviewees confirmed that tortoises were one of the main protein sources not only for people escaping war but also for soldiers operating in forested zones. For instance, in January–February 2018, Luiselli, Fa, and Magnusson did not find any K. homeana during two weeks of field surveys in the mature forests of the Nimba mount region. It is more than likely that the species has recently become increasingly rare throughout Liberia.

Cote d'Ivoire - Recent surveys from 2015 through 2020 have been made sporadically by Luiselli, Gonedele Bi, and associates, and since 2017 by Diagne and associates. Historical records (summarized in Iverson 1992, Luiselli and Diagne 2013, and TTWG 2017) have shown that the species is found only in the south, where it was reported to be locally common by hunters in 2010. The species has been found in some localities in Grand Bereby, Tai National Park, Azagny National Park, and Banco forest National Park and also in the forested areas surrounding Abidjan. In Banco NP and in the forest fragments surrounding Abidjan, however, the species has not been recorded in 2019–2020 despite intense field searching (Gonedele Bi and Luiselli, unpubl. data). Interview surveys with local villagers have suggested that this species may still be relatively widespread in the south of the country, but in decline (Luiselli et al. 2018).
