Although rapid infrastructure development is likely creating one of the biggest challenges for the conservation of migratory and nomadic ungulates, No Net Loss (NNL) or Net Positive Impact (NPI) policies adopted by industry, and newly emerging standards on Biodiversity Offsets (BBOP 2012) are powerful tools that may enable economic development to combine with biodiversity conservation, and offsets may actually provide a more flexible tool to conserve nomadic species (Bull et al. 2013). In Mongolia, the largest mine Oyu Tolgoi is operating on a NPI policy and Asiatic Wild Asses are a key species of concern.

Reintroductions have re-established the Asiatic Wild Ass in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Israel and somewhat expanded its range in Turkmenistan. The reintroduced populations contribute ~8% to the global population, but only managed to reoccupy a tiny fraction of the species former range. New reintroductions are currently discussed in Kazakhstan and Iran. However, care has to be taken that reintroduction projects do not distract attention and funds from conserving the remaining autochthonous populations.

Whereas increasing monitoring and research efforts are made in Mongolia, Israel, Xinjiang province in China, India and Bahram-e-Goor in Iran, little systematic information is available from Inner Mongolia and Gansu province in China, Touran protected area complex in Iran, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. Furthermore, major research gaps exist regarding: i) the human dimension of Asiatic Wild Ass management and conservation, ii) site specific population dynamics parameters, iii) triggers, drivers, and scale of nomadic or seasonal movements, iv) impact and mitigation of barriers.

A Programme of Work for the CMS Central Asian Mammal Initiative (CAMI) was agreed during the Stakeholder Meeting on the Conservation of Large Mammals in Central Asia, Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan (2325 September 2014) and included a recommendation to develop a single-species action plan for the Asiatic Wild Ass as a high priority.

rationale: The species is listed Near Threatened, suspected to be close to meeting Vulnerable under criterion A2, i.e. a decline of more than 20% over 3 generations (15 years), based on increasing levels of bushmeat hunting across its range, with documented local declines and extirpations. Its long-term future will be closely linked to the preservation of substantial areas of relatively unmodified equatorial forest.
habitat: Inhabits primary and relatively unmodified equatorial forests ranging from lowland to mid elevations. While it shows a preference for high primary rainforest, it may occupy patches of forest within savanna mosaics; also occurs in old farmbush and old secondary forest (Kingdon and Feer 2013).
threats: The major threats to this species include bushmeat hunting, which takes place across its range (using both cable snares and nets) and habitat loss and degradation (particularly in the face of expanding human settlement), especially given its preference for primary forest. The combination of systematic habitat destruction and the commercialization of hunting and trapping likely will ensure the eventual elimination of Bay Duiker outside protected areas (Kingdon and Feer 2013). Even then they are unlikely to survive in smaller protected areas because of habitat degradation and poaching: in Ghana, for example, this species has been extirpated from six parks and protected areas (Kingdon and Feer 2013), and Van Vliet et al. (2007) recorded its likely extirpation from Ipassa Natural Reserve in NE Gabon.
population: Population densities are summarized by Wilson (2001) and Kingdon and Feer (2013). East (1999) produced a total population estimate of 725,000. While its numbers are generally stable in the less disturbed forests where hunting pressures are relatively low, its overall numbers are in decline because of loss of habitat and over-hunting for meat in other parts of its range (East 1999).
range: The Bay Duiker has a disjunct distribution, occurring in the forests of West Africa from Guinea-Bissau to Togo; and in Central Africa, east of the Niger River to the montane forests in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and south to north-east Angola to about 11°S. There are no confirmed records from Gambia or Benin (Kingdon and Feer 2013, and references therein). Formerly occurred in Uganda, but now extirpated (East 1999).
useTrade: The Bay Duiker is a popular target for hunters, it is hunted across its entire range, year-round and at increasingly intense and unregulated levels (Kingdon and Feer 2013). Studies in Equatorial Guinea, W Cameroon and Central African Republic have shown that current harvest rates are entirely unsustainable (Fa et al. 1995, Noss 1998, Muchaal and Ngandjui 1999). In the Central African Republic, Bay Duikers accounted for 6.8% of all animals captured with nets (Noss 1998) and in Nigeria they were among the top five most hunted species in a bushmeat study (Fa et al. 2006).
conservationActions:
The Bay Duiker occurs in a number of protected areas including: Sapo NP (Liberia), Taï NP (Côte d'Ivoire), Bia and Kakum NPs (Ghana), Campo-Ma'an, Lobéké NPs and Dja Wildlife Refuge (Cameroon), Dzanga-Sangha and Bangassou (Central African Republic), Monte Alén NP (Equatorial Guinea), Ivindo, Loango, Lope, Minkebe Mouakalaba-Doudou NPs (Gabon), Odzala and Nouabale-Ndoki NPs and Léfini Faunal Reserve (Congo) and Kahuzi-Biega, Maiko and Salonga NPs (DR Congo) (East 1999, Wilson 2001, Kingdon and Feer 2013).

Listed in CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Hoolock tinxiang is considered Endangered A4cd. A suspected population decline caused by significant and accelerating rates of deforestation is projected to continue and perhaps accelerate. Combined with the facts that more than 90% of the population is believed to occur outside of protected areas, and the species continues to be hunted for food and medicinal purposes, a population loss equalling or exceeding 50% can be anticipated over three generations (between the years 2000 and 2045).
habitat:
This gibbon is a forest-dweller that inhabits primary evergreen, scrub and semi-deciduous hill forest, as well as mountainous broadleaf forest, but it cannot survive in pine-dominated forest. It ranges up to 2,700 m in elevation in Mt. Gaoligong (P.-F. Fan et al. 2013). The annual mean temperature is 13.3 °C and 13.1°C at two sites of Mt. Gaoligong. Gibbon habitat can be covered by snow in cold winters.

Two habituated groups are well studied by Fan Peng-Fei. and his team. Annual diet of a group in Mt. Gaoligong comprised 49.1% fruit (non-fig fruit 35.6%and fig 13.5%), 43.3% leaves (buds, young and mature leaves), 5.3% invertebrates and bird chicks, 1.8% flowers, and 0.6% others. Individuals prefer ripe fruits when they are available. They shift their diet to leaves and buds and  increased feeding time when fruits and figs are not available (P.-F. Fan et al. 2013). Groups use large home ranges (93 and 178 ha for two groups), and use different sections monthly (P.-F. Fan et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2014). Their daily travel distance varied from month to month (group BB: mean = 1,308 ± SD 735 m, range = 272–3,705 m, N = 60 days; group NA: mean = 1126 ± SD 488 m, range = 345–2,606 m, N = 52 days (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017), mostly depends on their diet and food availability. They decrease travel distance when they eat more leaves (Zhang et al. 2014).

Adults live in pairs and coordinate their singing to produce duet bouts that lasted for an average 25.5 min. Paired adults never produce solo bouts unless they are separated by human disturbances. The singing rate (number of bouts/number of monitoring days) of four groups in Mt. Gaoligong range from 7.5% to 31.4% which was lower than other gibbon populations, presumably due to low group density and prevalence of hunting at the study site (Yin et al., 2016).  One group stop calling for 68 days after at least 30 gunshots were heard from its home range.

Like other gibbons, Skywalker Hoolock Gibbons sleep in tall trees, and rarely use the same tree on consecutive days. They travel very fast to enter sleeping trees 2-3 hours before sunset. They mostly sleep on branches of diameter less than 10 cm and close to tree tops. Anti-predation is an important factor that affects Skywalker Hoolock Gibbon’s sleeping behavior (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017).

Neighbouring groups rarely fight along territory borders. Only one inter-group conflict was recorded in four years (Yin et al. 2016).
threats:
In China, although commercial logging has been banned, Hoolock tinxiang is threatened by small-scale habitat loss, degradation, fragmentation, and hunting (Fan et al. 2011, Yin et al. 2016). Local people believe that the brain of hoolock gibbons can be used to cure epilepsy. Nearly half of the remnant population now live in agro-forestry complexes (e.g., cardamom cultivation). Although cardamom cultivation causes some negative effects on gibbons, these agro-forestry complexes provide important gibbon habitat provided they are not too fragmented and hunting is prohibited (Zhang et al. 2014).

In Myanmar, H. tinxiang remains threatened by habitat loss due largely to slash-and-burn agriculture, gold mining and logging, and secondarily by hunting for food and medicinal purposes (Ni et al. 2018).  Unfortunately, the species is not known to occur in any protected areas in this country.  According to the most recent Global Forest Watch (2019) data for Myanmar, the six administrative divisions in which H. tinxiang is believed to occur - Shan, Mandalay, Kayah, Bago, Kayan and Mon - have lost nearly 9% of their forest cover since 2000, are collectively losing forest at a rate above the national average, and that rate has accelerated significantly in recent years. The previous gibbon generation (2000–2015) could have been expected to decline at a corresponding rate, and the present generation (2016–2030) and subsequent generation (2031–2045) can be expected to decline at a corresponding rate as well - this would result in a population decline related to habitat loss of at least 30%.  Should the current rate of loss continue to accelerate, which it appears to be doing, and hunting continue as well, a decline in population approaching or exceeding 50% can easily be anticipated.
population:
In China, the population is estimated to be approximately 200 individuals in nine (9) subpopulations (Fan et al. 2017).

In Myanmar, population estimates have ranged between 10,000 and 50,000 individuals (Geissmann et al. 2013). Even at the lower end of that range, the Myanmar population would represent at least 98% of the species' total.

Based on deforestation data for Myanmar since 2000, the region inhabited by this species has already experienced a significant and accelerating loss of forest. It is not known to occur in any protected areas of that country. Continued deforestation over the current and subsequent generation (2019 to 2045), combined with hunting for food and medicinal purposes) could plausibly result in a population reduction exceeding 50%.
range: In Myanmar, this species is found between the Irrawaddy-Nmai Hka River and the Salween River (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017). In China, wild individuals are confirmed to occur on Mt. Gaoligong. Historical museum specimens are also known from further south at Gokteik, Shan States, northern Myanmar (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017).
useTrade: In Myanmar, commercial logging is ongoing, and hunting is serious problem. Nearly every year, a few small juveniles and infants of hoolock gibbons (mostly H. leuconedys) are illegally exported to China (Ni et al., 2018).
conservationActions:
Half of the remnant Chinese population of Hoolock tinxiang  occurs in the Gaoligong National Nature Reserve (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017). A small NGO (Cloud Mountain Conservation) is working with local governments and forestry bureaus to protect this species and its habitat in China. Cloud Mountain Conservation educate local residents, especially school children, around Skywalker Hoolock Gibbon habitat, and support reserves to increase patrol.

Although a number of wildlife sanctuaries can be found within the range of Hoolock tinxiang in Myanmar, none are reported to harbor this species.

rationale: Piliocolobus oustaleti is listed as Vulnerable, despite having a large geographic range, as this genetically, morphologically and ecologically variable taxon has declined over the past decade or more, and the decline is expected to accelerate in the future. Like all other red colobus species (Struhsaker 2005), Oustalet’s Red Colobus is slow moving and is easily hunted. Hunting threatens populations in a number of areas, including portions of the range with low human population densities. At the northern and eastern edges of its range, the primary threat to this species is habitat loss and degradation. Large areas of the range comprise areas of rapidly advancing deforestation and agricultural expansion (Harris et al. 2017) and the species now appears to be absent in a number of locations where it was recorded historically. Further loss, degradation and fragmentation of the species’ range are expected into the foreseeable future. Projected to 2035, it is suspected that the population decline will exceed 30% over 30 years (equivalent to three generations), thus qualifying P. oustaleti as Vulnerable under criterion A4cd.
habitat:
Oustalet’s Red Colobus shows at least three distinct ecological modes, each covering significant portions of the range. It is found in contiguous, mature primary lowland tropical moist forest; seasonally- or permanently-inundated swamp forest, and in gallery forest and isolated forest islands in savanna woodland.

Large contiguous lowland forest blocks that contain important populations of this red colobus are found in Ituri, Rubi Tele and Aketi in DRC and in northern Congo. In these areas, this red colobus is recorded mostly in primary evergreen forest, though it also uses older secondary forest, and appears to prefer riversides and swamp forests. The species uses a range of mature forest types. In the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, they are found in monodominant stands of Gilbertiodendron dewevrei, where they feed on flower buds and immature seeds during periods of mast flowering and fruiting (J. Hart, unpublished observations 2007). They do not occur in younger secondary forest. In lowland evergreen forests, P. oustaleti can form large groups where they are not hunted. Counts of up to 70 animals were made in some groups in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve in the past (Hart et al. 2008); up to 50 in 2011, but the more recent dataset (which only covers about a quarter of the reserve at the time of writing) suggests that group sizes are now smaller (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2018).

In the Ngotto Forest in CAR, this species only occurs in flooded riverine forests (Gautier-Hion & Brugière 2005). Galat-Luong & Galat (1979) reported that they spent 30% of their time below 10 m above ground and regularly enter into water to collect bulbs of aquatic plants. Large blocks of seasonally- or permanently-inundated forest are found in the west of the species range, in the confluence region of the Congo, Sangha and Ubangi rivers, including Lac Télé in Congo.

The eastern-most populations of P. oustaleti occupy small isolated forest islands and galleries on the Lake Albert escarpment. Semi-deciduous tree species dominate the high elevation gallery forests where P. oustaleti has been studied recently (Laudisoit et al. 2016, Scholier 2017). Home range size in some of these blocks is highly constrained, suggesting that these populations, which have no means of dispersal, are likely under periodic resource stress.
threats:
Habitat loss and hunting are the primary threats to this species. Habitat loss is particularly severe for the populations that occur in small forest islands and galleries at the northern and eastern limits of the range. Sources of deforestation in this environment include growing numbers of small holder farmers, expansion of nomadic pastoralism, small-scale logging and charcoal production. These latter threats are growing in a zone where ready sources of timber and fuel wood are scarce. Even low levels of firewood, house pole collection and timber harvest could have severe impact on populations in these areas, as they are constrained to very small home ranges and may be exposed to periods of stress exacerbated by the removal of key resources.

In parts of DRC, in portions of the range originally covered by contiguous forest, there are growing halos of deforestation around the population centres of Bunia, Isiro, Buta, Lisala and Gemena. A band of forest loss and degradation up to 100 km wide now isolates P. oustaleti populations in the Abubumbazi forest block. Commercial scale oil-palm plantations established in the Lisala area have led to permanent loss of habitat. Areas showing high rates of deforestation affect about 25% of P. oustaleti’s range (Harris et al. 2017). Forest loss in the current geographic range of the taxon totaled around 15,000 km² between 2001 and 2016 (Global Forest Watch/WRI 2018).

Hunting, usually with shotguns, is a threat to P. oustaleti in a number of areas, including Buta and the Rubi-Télé Hunting Domain (T. Hart, pers. comm. 2007), and across the whole of northern Congo and southwestern CAR outside the areas protected by wildlife guards. Though hunting is not yet common in the Ituri forest, it appears to be a growing threat in the Ituri landscape, in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve and the adjacent, unprotected Mai Tatu forest (R. Mwinyihali, pers. comm. 2018). Widespread hunting was recorded in the Abubumbazi Forest in the northwest extreme of the species range in DRC, where no red colobus were recorded during a brief survey (J. Hart pers. obs. 1989). The bushmeat trade is active around Buta-Aketi (Hicks et al. 2010). Two red colobus were amng 169 monkey carcasses recorded for sale during 2007 and 2008 surveys (Hicks, unpublished data). One red colobus was among 21 identified monkey carcasses encountered between Banalia-Buta-Titulé in 2012 (Hicks 2014).
population: Given the size of its geographic range, Oustalet’s Red Colobus is likely to be among the more numerous of the red colobus taxa (Struhsaker and Grubb 2013). No estimates of P. oustaleti density are available; however, it has been recorded as common by a number of large-scale surveys. Piliocolobus oustaleti was the third most observed species in the flooded forests of Ngotto in southwestern CAR (Brugière et al. 2005), and was classified as common at eight of 12 survey sites covering the central portion of its range (Buta-Aketi Region) from 24 to 26° E (Hicks 2010, 2014, unpublished data). The species was among the most commonly recorded primates in surveys of the Okapi Wildlife Reserve between 1993 and 2011 (Grossman et al. 2008, Hart et al. 2008, Vosper et al. 2011) although the most recent information shows that its abundance has fallen relative to other species (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2018). A large area in the eastern Ituri forest (Mai Tatu) also harbours this red colobus, although again it is now one of the least commonly recorded (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2008, 2014).
range:
Piliocolobus oustaleti occurs in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Republic of Congo (Congo), and has been recorded historically or marginally in South Sudan. It is also present in the extreme southwest of the Central African Republic (CAR). Its extent of occurrence (EEO) is estimated at 766,035 km². The eastern limit of its range is at about 31°E and includes the gallery forests and forest islands on the escarpments above Lake Albert. The northernmost record for the species is 4.50 N is northeastern DRC (Garamba National Park; Groves 2007). North of the Uélé River headwaters, the species has been historically recorded sporadically in gallery forests and forest islands in savanna from northern DRC to southern South Sudan. The Uélé River defines the northern limit of the range from about 210 through 270 E.  Historically, the species was recorded near the forest-savanna boundary between Lisala and Gemena (M. Collet unpublished data 1983). The southern limits of its range are the Aruwimi (Ituri) River and the Congo River to its confluence with the Sangha river at 1013’ S. The western limit is the Sangha River up to the savanna-forest ecotone. P. oustaleti ranges from 350 m elevation at the confluence of the Sangha and Congo rivers, to 1,850 m in the gallery forests above Lake Albert.

The species appears to be absent from a number of locations at its northern and eastern limits, where it was known historically, including Garamba National Park (K. Smith pers. comm. 2018). Contrary to Gautier-Hion et al. (1999), P. oustaleti does not occur north of the Uélé River west of 27 0 E. This includes large undisturbed blocks of closed forest in the Bili-Gangu region where recent surveys documented a rich forest primate fauna, but failed to find this species (Hart 2012; Hicks 2010, 2014). It appears that the populations that have been documented in small forest islands and galleries in the northern Uélé headwaters, never ranged west across the open savannas of the Ango-Digba region to reach these closed forests. The Uélé River, at this longitude, apparently represents a major barrier to dispersal by populations from the forest blocks to the south.
useTrade: This species is hunted illegally. Its meat is eaten and traded.
conservationActions:
All red colobus are classed as totally protected species at a national level in CAR, Congo and DRC (Central African Republic 1984, MEFDD 2011, Enerunga 2006).

Piliocolobus oustaleti is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

The largest populations of P. oustaleti remaining occur in national parks and reserves that protect large blocks of habitat, including in DRC: Okapi Wildlife Reserve, Rubi-Télé Hunting Domain and the Reserve Naturelle de Ngiri; in Congo: Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park and Lac Télé Community Reserve; and in CAR: Dzanga-Sangha Protected Areas complex and the Mbaéré-Bodingué National Park (Ngotto Forest).

Protected areas where hunting is controlled are the most important mechanisms for protection of this species.

rationale: Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed as CR A3c. This species is endemic to forests along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River. The current population is estimated at ca 1,000 individuals. Future population reduction of 80% or more is possible should the rate of decline in forest cover approach levels reached several years back and continue for the next three generations (2019-2048). This is especially likely if the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) is officially annulled, an action now being considered by national authorities. The entire population lies in a politically insecure area over which there is a low level of conservation activity, and much unplanned, unregulated, and unsustainable exploitation of natural resources.
habitat: Piliocolobus rufomitratus occupies riverine and flood-plain forests. This folivorous species has a home range of ca 4–19 ha (Decker 1994). Mean group size is ca 13 individuals (Butynski and Mwangi 1994) with generally one adult male (Marsh 1979, Decker 1994, Mbora 2003). Piliocolobus rufomitratus is arboreal, but must come to the ground (rarely) to move between, and colonise, distant forest patches.
threats:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus has declined as a result of several causes, including: (a) drastic changes in vegetation due to dam construction, irrigation projects, and water diversion, which affect the water table and the frequency and severity of flooding which, in turn, affect the amount and quality of habitat; (b) forest clearance for agriculture; (c) fires that destroy forests; (d) habitat degradation due to livestock and the unsustainable collection of wood and other forest products; (e) selective felling of fig trees for canoes; and (f) corruption, inter-ethnic violence, and insecurity (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; De Jong and Butynski 2012; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013; Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016; Butynski and De Jong 2019). Because all remaining forests inhabited by P. rufomitratus are small and seriously threatened, the long-term survival of the species is in question.

There has been considerable alteration of river flow volume and the flood cycle by five hydroelectric power dams up-river (Butynski 1995). A sixth dam, the High Grand Falls Dam, is under construction (Hamerlynck et al. 2012, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016). The High Grand Falls Dam, the second largest dam in Africa, will be accompanied by large-scale irrigation schemes and water transfer to the ‘Lamu Port and Lamu Southern Sudan-Ethiopia Transport Corridor’. The establishment of this dam is expected to have additional negative impacts on the forests of the Lower Tana River and, therefore, on P. rufomitratus.

One special concern is the rapidly growing human population in the region. Another is the possible annulment of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR; 169 km²) which the High Court of Kenya ordered in January 2007. According to the Kenya Wildlife Act 2013, Section 37, change of boundaries or revocation of a National Reserve can only be published by the Cabinet Secretary and approved by Parliament. Change or revocation can only be recommended if they do not endanger any species or critical habitat. As such, it seems unlikely that annulment will occur, despite the court ruling in 2007.

About 35% of P. rufomitratus occur in the TRPNR. Even with the continued existence of the TRPNR the long-term survival of P. rufomitratus is not certain, as the high level of insecurity and inadequate law enforcement in the region is expected to continue (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; Butynski and De Jong 2018).

According to Global Forest Watch data, Kenya's Tana River region has lost 16% of its forest cover since the turn of the century, tropical forest habitat being reduced from approximately 60,000 to 50,000 hectares. Although the annual rate of loss has remained fairly consistent throughout this period (530 ha/yr avg), it has spiked several times to more than double or triple that rate. Should the TRPNR be annulled and/or peak rates of deforestation be reached again, it is conceivable that this species could lose 80% or more of its habitat by mid-century.
population:
Total number of Piliocolobus rufomitratus estimated at 1,100–1,300 individuals in 1994 (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995). Total population today ca 1,000 individuals and is expected to continue to decline (Mbora 2003, Karere et al. 2004, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2018).

Although the annual rate of habitat loss of this species has remained fairly consistent (530 ha/yr avg), it has spiked several times to more than double or triple that rate. Should the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) be annulled and/or peak rates of deforestation be reached again, it is conceivable that this species could lose > 80% of its habitat by mid-century.
range:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus is a medium-sized monkey that occurs along the lower Tana River and in the Tana Delta, north coast of Kenya. It occurs along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River from Kipende in the north to Mitipani in the south where the Lamu-Garsen Road crosses the Tana River floodplain. A small number of individuals may still exist in the Tana Delta. This species lives in about 34 distinct, small (1–500 ha) forests, some of which are isolated. Some of the more important forests are Guru South, Sifa East, Baomo South, Mnazini East, Bubesa West 1 and Hewani South 2 (Butynski and Mwangi 1994).

Piliocolobus rufomitratus is broadly sympatric with Cercocebus galeritus, Cercopithecus mitis albotorquatus, Paragalago cocos and Otolemur garnettii lasiotis, and narrowly sympatric on the forest edge with Papio cynocephalus ibeanus, Chlorocebus pygerythrus hilgerti and Galago senegalensis braccatus (De Jong and Butynski 2009, 2012; Butynski and De Jong 2019).
conservationActions:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Given the current poor management of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR), the continued clearing of forest and settlement of people within the TRPNR, and the low level of conservation activity in the region, the long-term survival of P. rufomitratus seems bleak. A small number of P. rufomitratus may still be present in the Tana River Delta. This delta became a Ramsar Site in 2012, but the forests there continue to be destroyed and, in any case, the number of P. rufomitratus there is small (Butynski and de Jong 2019). Otherwise, the Tana Delta holds no protected area.

Ndera Community Conservancy, established in 2010 with the help of the Northern Rangeland Trusts (www.nrt-kenya.org), aims to conserve 150 km² of the lower Tana River and to improve the viability of forest patches within and outside the TRPNR (Mbora and Allen 2011, J. King pers. comm. 2016). The Ndera Community Conservancy provides an opportunity for improved conservation of those forests upon which P. rufomitratus depends.

Stringent habitat protection is required for all forests of the Lower Tana River and Tana Delta. The Mchelelo Research Station in the TRPNR needs to be rehabilitated and re-established.

Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed as one of the world’s 25 most threatened primates (Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016).

rationale: Very little is known about the population status of Miopithecus talapoin, but recent information shows that, despite its small size, this primate is now hunted for bushmeat in Angola and Democratic Republic of Congo (Thompson 2000, Bersacola et al. 2014, C. Hines. pers. comm. 2017). In addition, habitat loss due to commercial timber harvesting is occurring at key forest sites in its geographic range, especially in Angola (Bersacola et al. 2015, Cáceres et al. 2016). The species is now rarely seen in the largest protected area where it occurs (in Angola) and which is being heavily encroached. It is suspected that the overall population decline since 2005 and projected to 2029 (a 24-year period, i.e. three generations) will exceed 30% and this taxon is therefore listed as Vulnerable A4cd.
habitat: The Southern Talapoin is a strictly riverine species, limited to dense evergreen vegetation on the banks of rivers that often flow through miombo (Brachystegia) woodland or, increasingly, cultivated areas (Gautier-Hion 2013, Kingdon 2015). The species has also been observed in deciduous forests in northwestern Angola (C. Hines pers. comm. 2016). Home ranges of this species are likely to be larger and densities lower than for the Northern Talapoin because in the drier southern part of its range, forest strips are narrower and resources scarcer. Longer dry seasons and less extensive flooding under generally cooler and drier climates may have favoured the Southern Talapoin's more terrestrial habits (Kingdon 1997). The diet is likely to be mainly fruits, seeds, young foliage and invertebrates.
threats:
In Angola, the species has been seen at roadside bushmeat stalls (Bersacola et al. 2014, C. Hines pers. comm. 2017), and these monkeys are certainly hunted in Quicama National Park (T. Ron pers. obs. 2018). In DRC, they have been reported to be accidentally caught in snares, but consumed nonetheless (Thompson 2000).

The Angolan forests where talapoins occur are rapidly being cleared for commercial timber harvesting (Bersacola et al. 2015, Cáceres et al. 2016). Hansen et al. (2013) highlighted Angola as one of the countries with the fastest increase in forest cover loss. Approximately 2.4% of tree cover in its range was lost between 2001 and 2016 (GFW-WRI 2018). However, because this species lives in narrow strips of riverine forests, the true loss of habitat may differ from this estimate. There is no particularly evident riverine pattern of forest loss on the GFW visualisation, but future analysis would clarify this.
population: Very little is known about the population status of Miopithecus talapoin, but it is thought to be decreasing across its range. Recent information from Angola shows that the species is being hunted for bushmeat. Plus this monkey is now rarely seen in the largest protected area in which it occurs, which is being heavily encroached.
range:
The Southern Talapoin lives in southwestern DRC and northern Angola, and its geographic range covers approximately 400,000 km². The northern limit of its range is the left bank of the Congo River up to about 3°S. It is found in the coastal watersheds south of the Congo River, notably the Mebridege River, Loge River, Cuanza River, Nhia River and Cuvo River (spilling over into the upper reaches of the Cuango River).

This species is found along the coast of Angola to about 13’S, and into DRC as far as the Cuango River and on both sides of the Kasai River (Thompson 2000, Groves 2001, Bersacola et al. 2014). Talapoins have been sighed at Lac Ma Vallée (Dinets 2009), which is close to the DRC capital of Kinshasa. One record near the village of Mimia at around 20°00’E, 2°29’S, southwest of Salonga National Park and roughly 160 km north of the Kasai River (Thompson 2000), suggests that the Southern Talapoin may also occur in the area between the Kasai River and the location noted by Thompson.
useTrade: This species is hunted for local consumption and sale at bushmeat markets.
conservationActions:
This species is listed under Appendix II of CITES, and as Class B on the African Convention. It is not known whether this species occurs in all protected areas in its geographic range. Those protected areas include: Quiçama (Kissama) National Park (officially documented as 9,960 km²) in Angola, Bombo Lumene Reserve (2,184 km²) and Swa-Kibula Reserve (1,003 km²) in DRC. It has been recorded in both Quiçama and Swa Kibula in the recent past (Dino 2014).

According to the range map, it may also occur in the Buffalo Partial Reserve (400 km²) in Angola) and the Mangai Reserve (1,903 km²) in DRC, but the former has not been under any protection or management for decades. The Quiçama National Park is by far the largest protected area in which it occurs, but park has lost 160 km² of forest cover since 2001 (Global Forest Watch 2018), and this loss is continuing apace (T. Ron pers. obs. 2018).

rationale: Lophocebus aterrimus is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A2cd. Poaching of this species for the bushmeat trade is intensifying, and much of the forest in its range is now almost “empty” of large mammals. Because of its relatively large body size, the Black Mangabey is more attractive to hunters than the smaller Cercopithecus monkeys with which it shares its range. The species is also threatened by habitat loss and is suspected to have declined by at least 30% over the past three generations (30 years).
habitat: This species is found in primary and secondary moist forests. In Salonga National Park, the Black Mangabey also uses swamp forests, but does not occupy swamp in Lomako (McGraw 1994). It uses all forest strata (especially the middle canopy layers), but seldom descends to the ground (Horn 1987, McGraw 1994). Its diet consists largely of fruits and seeds, with high rates of nectarivory in some months of the year. Foraging activity is concentrated in the early morning (Horn 1987, Gautier-Hion & Maisels 1994, McGraw 1994).
threats:
Little is known about the status of this species. However, it is subject to intense, uncontrolled poaching for its meat in most parts of its range. It is also threatened by loss of forest habitat in the south of its range. Bushmeat data collected along the Congo River suggest that very few of these monkeys have been sold at the markets during the past decade; implying that very few are left in the forest (Laudisoit, pers. obs. late 2010s). Black Mangabeys are large-bodied, and provide more meat per unit effort than the smaller guenons (Cercopithecus spp.) with which they share the habitat. They are, therefore, more attractive to hunters, especially if shotguns are used (a shotgun cartridge costs about US$1 in the region). Quantitatively, a recce survey between the two sectors of the Salonga National Park in 2009 (Maisels et al. 2009) showed that monkeys in general, and Black Mangabeys in particular, were very rare to the west of the park headquarters at Monkoto, and increasingly rare to absent at the western extreme (where the highest concentrations of people are located in the corridor). Overall encounter rate was 0.13 groups/km. A recce survey carried out at the same time and using the same survey method in the unprotected Sankuru Reserve (Liengola et al. 2010) recorded the species only 10 times in 400 km of survey effort – an encounter rate of only 0.025/km walked, and one-fifth of that recorded in the Salonga corridor, which was (and still is) at least partially protected by forest guards.

In Salonga in 2016–2017, encounter rate of groups on transects varied between 0.2 (southern sector of the park) to 0.3 (northern sector) (Wildlife Conservation Society unpublished data 2016 and 2017, Ikati et al. 2017), so still an order of magnitude greater than encounter rates outside the park. It is likely that most unprotected forests in the range of this species are defaunated of the larger-bodied species, including Black Mangabeys. They had completely vanished from the Swa-Kabula Reserve in the southwest of the country before 1990 (Dino 2014). The same is likely to have occurred throughout their range, especially where human populations can travel freely and rapidly through the habitat (the case in savanna-forest mosaics south of the Kasai River).

Rates of forest loss differ in the geographic ranges of the two subspecies. In the 130,000 km² range of L. a. opdenboschi, about 99,500 km² has forest cover (this area is the savanna-forest mosaic south of the Kasai River). A total of 3.7% of the forest cover that existed in 2001 was lost between 2001 and 2016 (GFW/WRI 2018). In L. a. aterrimus range, in the more closed-canopy continuous Congo Basin forests further north, the forest cover loss was only 2% during the same period – just over half of the rate of loss further south (of the subspecies' total range of 585,300 km²).
population: Although Lophocebus aterrimus is widespread, its total population size is unknown and surveys are needed. Several decades ago, densities of around 70 individuals/km² were recorded in Lomako and Lac Tumba in DRC (Horn 1987, McGraw 1994). The population is suspected to have undergone a reduction of at least 30% over the last 30 years (three generations) based on intensifying hunting pressure on this species for the bushmeat trade and habitat loss in the south of its range.
range:
Lophocebus aterrimus occurs south of the Congo River in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), in lowland rainforest areas of the southwest Congo Basin. It is also found in gallery forests and more fragmented forests reaching down into northern Angola to about 8°45’ S (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). The western, northern and eastern limits of the geographic range are the left bank of the Congo River. South of the Kasai River, the taxon is limited to the west by the Kwango River, and to the south by the forest-savanna boundary.

There are two subspecies (following Grubb et al. 2003): L. aterrimus aterrimus is found in the central Congo basin; L. a. opdenboschi is/was found in a very small area of northeastern Angola (Machado 1969, Gautier-Hion 2013), and in southwestern DRC. The two subspecies are separated by the Kasai River, which cuts diagonally across the range at roughly 3° to 4° S. The Black Mangabey was extirpated from the Swa-Kibula Reserve, a protected area on the Angolan border, before 1990 (Dino 2014). It is possible that it has been extirpated from Angola, and from much of the area south of the Kasai River.
useTrade: Illegally hunted for local consumption
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and as Class B of the African Convention. It is on the partially protected species list in DRC (Enerunga 2006). In Angola, all monkeys have been officially protected by Presidential Decree since 2005.

It is present in Salonga National Park (which is probably its main stronghold), Lomami National Park, where it is protected by wildlife guards (Hart et al. 2012), and has been recorded in Sankuru Natural Reserve (in very low numbers). It is also found in Lomako-Yokokala Wildlife Reserve (Lushimba 2012). In the west of their range, they still occur in the Tumba-Ledima Natural Reserve (Beudels-Jamar et al. 2015, Petre and Haggis 2017).

rationale: Olive Colobus (Procolobus verus) is listed as Vulnerable, compared to Near Threatened in the previous assessment, as this species is estimated to have undergone a decline exceeding 30% over the past three generations (approximately 27 years), mainly as a result of continuing habitat loss and hunting. Data summarised by FAO (2015) show that in the 1990–2015 period there was a 22.5% reduction of forest across the eight West African countries where the Olive Colobus occurs. When combined with evidence of continued heavy hunting pressure for the bushmeat trade, those data can be used to suspect at least a 30% reduction in population size in a 27-year period. The cryptic nature of the Olive Colobus, and its ability to survive in riverine forests and small forest fragments, and to adapt to some anthropogenic disturbance, have no doubt enabled the species to persist in many parts of their range. However, their decline is expected to continue in the future and, given an accelerating loss of forest habitat in West Africa (which already has one of the highest rates in the world) and continuing hunting pressure, both of which are related to continued high rates of human population growth in West Africa, Procolobus verus is evaluated as Vulnerable under both A2cd and A4cd.
habitat: This species, the smallest of all colobine monkeys, inhabits the forest zone of West Africa and is often associated with areas of secondary growth within high forest, and with swamp forests. The Olive Colobus has also been observed in forest galleries in dry forest regions. It can survive in quite small and degraded forest fragments. Olive Colobus are arboreal and most commonly occupy the lower and middle forest strata, but they will occasionally descend and move on the ground. They are cryptic in colouration and behaviour, live in small social groups, and typically associate closely with other forest monkeys, especially Cercopithecus species (Oates and Whitesides 1990, Nobimè and Sinsin 2003, Oates 2011, Oates and Korstjens 2013). The monkeys prefer dense growth below 20 m, but may ascend higher when feeding or moving in the company of other species. The diet of the Olive Colobus is comprised mainly of leaves and leaf parts (75-90%), especially young leaves, along with flowers and unripe seeds (Oates and Korstjens 2013).
threats: This species is almost certainly declining due to loss of its forest habitats and hunting. Although the Olive Colobus can live in disturbed forests, even secondary forest is being replaced by farms and plantations in many parts of West Africa, and other species of monkey with which the Olive Colobus typically associates are being eliminated by hunting. Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone are among three of 10 countries in the world that had the fastest annual acceleration of tree cover loss in the 2001–2014 period, based on an analysis of satellite imagery, with Sierra Leone (once a stronghold for this species) recording the world’s second greatest annual forest loss rate of 12.6% (Petersen et al. 2015). In Nigeria, in the most easterly part of the species range, P. verus can be considered Endangered as a consequence of heavy hunting pressure and escalating habitat loss (R. Ikemeh pers. comm. 2016); data from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization show a 5% per annum loss of forest cover in Nigeria in the 2010–2015 period compared with 2.7% per annum in 1990–2000 (FAO 2015). The same data analysis (FAO 2015) shows that in the eight countries in which Olive Colobus populations have been found (Benin, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Togo) there was a combined total forest loss in the 1990–2015 period of 22.5%. A separate analysis by the U.S. Geological Survey’s EROS Centre shows a total forest loss in the Upper Guinea region (excluding Benin and Nigeria) of 25% between 1975 and 2013 (CILSS 2016). Given the continuation of uncontrolled hunting of monkeys across much of this species’ range, it is suspected that P. verus has suffered a population reduction of at least 30% in the last three generations, and that this decline will accelerate in the future.
population: Although quite secretive, Olive Colobus are still present in many parts of their range; however, they have naturally low population densities (McGraw 2007) and are almost certainly declining in numbers. Surveys in Kakum Conservation Area, Ghana, in 2009–2010 encountered this species at a lower rate than reported from surveys in 1993 (Wiafe 2016). Surveys in southwestern Ghana in 2012 reported its presence in the forest reserves of Krokosua Hills, Ayum, Subin, Bia North, Mpameso, Bia-Tano and Bokoni, at encounter rates of between 0.03 and 0.13 groups per km, and in Bia National Park at 0.23 groups per km (Danquah et al. 2012). In Côte d’Ivoire, recent surveys reported the presence of the species in several protected and unprotected areas, but at very low densities (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2014). In Côte d’Ivoire the most important populations occur in the Tanoé Forest and in Taï National Park, where estimated densities are 1.9 groups per sq. km (S. Gonedelé Bi pers. obs. 2009) and 2.65 groups per km² (Covey 2009) respectively. In the 1980s, the density in secondary and riverine forest at Tiwai Island, Sierra Leone, was 1.2 groups per km² (Oates et al. 1990). A recent survey of Benin found them to have a more widespread distribution than previously known (Djego-Djossou et al. 2014), but with a small total population; none were observed during a 2015 survey in neighbouring Togo (G. Segniagbeto pers. comm. 2016).
range: The Olive Colobus is confined to the forests of West Africa, and is discontinuously distributed from southern Sierra Leone and Guinea to south-east Nigeria (Oates 1981, 2011). The main discontinuity in their recent distribution appears to be in western Nigeria, between the border with the Republic of Benin and the River Niger; populations are known in the Niger Delta and in southern Benue State, Nigeria, just east of the Niger. However, the species’ distribution in eastern Ghana, and Togo and Benin also appears to be very patchy. In a few localities (e.g., Taï National Park, Côte d'Ivoire) it is relatively numerous.
useTrade: Procolobus verus and other forest monkeys species in West Africa are widely hunted to provide meat for local consumption, among families and communities.
conservationActions: The Olive Colobus is listed as a Class A species under the African Convention, and under Appendix II of CITES. It occurs in a number of protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, despite increasing hunting pressure on this taxon. Cercopithecus cephus is under threat in large parts of Cameroon, Central African Republic (close to Bangui) and Democratic Republic of Congo, and has become rare in most of central and southern Congo, but remains common and widespread in Gabon and northern Congo. A population decrease is suspected; however, data needed to quantify the threats and any resulting declines are lacking.
habitat: This diurnal, arboreal species is largely associated with lowland tropical rainforest, preferring the lower levels; often in vegetation tangles; also be found in secondary habitat types and gallery forests (Gautier-Hion 2013). Common in mangroves along the coast of Congo (Maisels and Cruickshank 1996). Primarily a frugivorous species; also eats seeds, leaves, arthropods, fledgling birds and eggs (Tutin and White 1998). Density ranges from 4 to 66 individuals/km²; group size up to 22 individuals (Gautier-Hion 2013).
threats:
This species has been heavily impacted by habitat loss through deforestation and hunting for bushmeat. Improvements in the transport network across the species’ range have led to increased commercialisation of offtake from previously subsistence villages. Across the region, village hunters now regularly sell 40-60% of their offtake (Abernethy et al. 2013). C. cephus (along with other Cercopithecus species) is commonly traded in many rural markets across its range (Fa & Brown, 2009). In general, primates decline under sustained hunting pressure and increasing human populations (Fa et al. 2015).

Of the three subspecies, C.c. ngottoensis is likely to be under highest threat, due to its relatively small geographic range and a higher proportion of that range experiencing high hunting pressure and possible disruption from armed conflicts.
population: Cercopithecus cephus has become extremely rare due to intense hunting for bushmeat, especially the savanna-forest mosaics of central Congo, the forests of coastal Congo outside protected areas, and in DRC. Hunting pressure has resulted in the species becoming extremely rare in parts of southern Congo (Kouilou in Congo: Dowsett and Dowsett-Lemaire 1991; Lefini and Lesio-Louna: Nganga et al. 2006). A 2011 survey that covered the whole of Equatorial Guinea recorded this species only a handful of times. In northern Congo and much of Gabon, this monkey is still common and widespread. Data are lacking to quantify threats and resulting declines.
range:
Cercopithecus cephus ranges from the Sanaga River in Cameroon south and east to the Congo River, to the lower Congo in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The northern limit appears to be the forest-savanna ecotone at about 5 to 6 degrees North. The area covered by the species distribution is about 836,650 km². The 2008 Red List assessment did not include the areas of the Mayombe in Gabon and Congo near the Gabon-Congo border, but they are still present in southern coastal Gabon (Aba’a et al. 2011, Mackaya 2011, R.J. Parnell pers. obs.) and Congo (MDDEFE 2010), and in southern Republic of Congo (Inkamba-Nkulu 2005). They were also in the Dimonika area in southern Congo to at least 1995 (Feer 1990, Ihobe 1995) and may still be there. 

Three subspecies are recognised: C. c. cephus occurs within about 70% of the species’ range, in Cameroon, Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, Congo and Central African Republic (CAR). It is limited to the north by the Sanaga River in Cameroon and the Ogooué River in the south. C. c. cephodes occurs south of the Ogooué River in Gabon, Congo, Angola (Cabinda) and a small area of coastal DRC, where its southern limit is the Congo River. A third subspecies C. c. ngottoensis is found in CAR, where it is known from the Kadei-Mambéré region east to the Ubangui, occurring as far north as Bangui and northern Congo; the southwestern limit is unknown.
useTrade: This species is hunted illegally for local consumption and sale to bushmeat markets.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES, Annex B of the EU Wildlife Trade Regulations and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

This widespread species is present in all of the protected areas in Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, most PAs in Congo, in the forested PAs of southwest CAR, and in PAs south of the Sanaga in Cameroon up to, and including, the southern sector of the Mbam et Djerem National Park (Maisels et al. 2009). Occurs in one PA in Cabinda (Mayombe National Park; Ron 2011) and used to be - and may still be found - in the Luki Reserve in DRC (Pendje and Baya 1992). 

The recently described ngottoensis subspecies is present in the proposed Mbaere-Bodingue park in CAR, but absent from the Dzanga-Ndoki National Park and the contiguous Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park in Congo, and has not been recorded in any other protected area in that region (Brugière et al. 2005).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, Cercopithecus hamlyni has undergone past reductions and continues to decline due to hunting and, increasingly, to habitat loss and fragmentation. The primary drivers of these threats—human population growth and the expansion of artisanal mining—are likely to increase into the foreseeable future. Most of the species’ range is in a region of endemic and ongoing human conflict, which has exacerbated known threats, and weakened organised efforts to protect these primates. It is suspected that the population decline of C. hamlyni will continue, resulting in an overall population reduction of more than 30% over a 30-year time frame from 2003 to 2033 (given a 10-year generation length). The taxon thus meets the Vulnerable threshold for criterion A4cd.
habitat:
A predominantly terrestrial species recorded from lowland to mid-montane tropical moist forest and montane bamboo forest. In the lowland forest zone (450–1,000 m), which comprises the major portion of the range, C. hamlyni occurs mainly in primary forest areas. The species occupies older secondary forest in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, but does not favour young secondary forests, and is not known to occur in gallery forests in savannas at the southern limit of its range (Hart et al. 2013). The isolated forest blocks south of the species’ contiguous EOO, where C. hamlyni have been recorded historically, range in size from 200–450 km² and are located on small chains of hills. There is no evidence that these blocks were isolated due to historic human activities, and they may represent relictual range areas, isolated by climate-induced habitat change during the Quaternary or Holocene. In any case, they suggest that isolated populations of C. hamlyni may be able to persist even in a fragmented landscape. Further investigation of the current status of these populations, and exploration of other isolated forest massifs in this region for presence of the species is urgently needed.

Mean group size in the Kahuzi-Biega lowlands and Ituri Forest is 2–3 animals (Hall et al. 2002-2003), In Nyungwe National Park group size averaged 3.6 animals (Easton et al. 2011). These estimates are based on sightings of animals from line transects. However, given the difficulties of directly observing these monkeys, this may be an underestimate of group size. The species feeds primarily on the ground. Diet is poorly documented but known to include fruits and seeds. In the Ituri Forest (elevation 700–750 m) C. hamlyni forages opportunistically on sprouting seedlings when Gilbertiondendron dewevrei undergoes mast fruiting. Fungi and herbaceous vegetation are eaten during periods of fruit scarcity (Hart et al. 2013). The Nyungwe population feeds extensively on bamboo shoots, and this is likely to be the case in other montane locations such as Kahuzi-Biega and Mt. Tshiaberimu, where the species occurs in the bamboo zones. Given the range of habitats occupied, C. hamlyni appears to have a wide dietary tolerance with specialization based on local and seasonal food availability.

Leopards and crowned eagles are known to prey on C. hamlyni in the Ituri Forest; nonetheless, the species was recorded at a low frequency in one study of leopard diets (Hart et al. 1996).
threats:
This species is threatened by habitat loss and poaching. Habitat loss and degradation, due primarily to deforestation by shifting cultivators and small holder farmers, is the most significant threat at present and is growing rapidly. Forest loss in DRC increased by a factor of 2.5 between 2011 and 2017 (Harris et al. 2017). Forest loss and associated degradation have been particularly intense in the eastern and southern portions of C. hamlyni’s range. The impact is most severe in the submontane and montane portions of the range, where human population densities are highest.

Factors promoting habitat loss include rural population growth and expansion of artisanal mining. These will continue to prevail into the foreseeable future. Within the range of C. hamlyni, high rates of forest loss are particularly evident around growing settlements of Beni, Kalima, Kindu, Kisangani, Lubutu, Mambasa, Opienge and Punia. Deforestation and forest degradation are expanding along networks of abandoned roads emanating from these centres, leading to fragmentation of previously intact forest blocks. East of Kisangani, and in the peripheries of Kahuzi-Biega and Maiko national parks, large roadless forest blocks have been invaded by artisanal miners leading to new clearings in remote areas. A recent deforestation hotspot analysis (Harris et al. 2017) indicates that about 40% of C. hamlyni range has been affected by moderate to severe forest loss and degradation. Vast areas of newly-emerging deforestation hot spots intersect with intact primary forests and extend into several protected areas (Harris et al. 2017).

For the past two decades, eastern DRC has been the theatre of entrenched conflict promulgated by a multiplicity of rural militia, a number of whom are based in national parks. The militia attack and loot villages, and exploit artisanal mining or are involved in it themselves. The conflict has led to large movements of internally displaced people (IDPs) and has contributed to the opening of new settlements and expansion of existing settlements. In 2017, over 850,00 unsettled IDPs were registered in administrative territories within the geographic range of C. hamlyni (UNOCHA 2018).

Expanding settlement and artisanal mining are associated with increased hunting and poaching. Cercopithecus hamlyni is shy and difficult to detect. Although this species is not a frequent target of hunters, its terrestrial habits make it vulnerable to snares set for other species. A recent survey of bushmeat market vendors in Kalima, a mining centre in the southern portion of its range, revealed only one fresh C. hamlyni carcass among 38 primates (dried and fresh) on sale. According to vendors interviewed, as recently as five years ago, they could expect to offer 3–5 fresh C. hamlyni per day. Four hunters in three villages to the south and west of Kalima, bordering the region’s remaining forest areas, stated that snare captures of C. hamlyni have been declining for the past 15 years, and are now uncommon. (J. Hart unpublished data 2018).
population: Cercopithecus hamlyni is widespread and variably abundant. Important populations have been documented in the lowland sector of Kahuzi-Biega National Park, with densities of 5-7 individuals per km² (Hall et al. 2002-2003) and the species persists throughout this park (Kujirakwinja et al. 2015; Spira et al. 2015a, 2015b, 2017). Populations surveyed at montane sites at the species’ altitudinal limit appear to be small. In Nyungwe Nation al Park, encounter rates averaged 0.08 groups/km (Easton et al. 2011). Cercopithecus hamlyni is a cryptic and quiet species, which is difficult to census and characteristically moves away from observers before detection, therefore population estimates based on visual contact probably underestimate population sizes. Surveys at dawn in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve of “booming” male vocalisations suggest that C. hamlyni is locally common, and that this is a stronghold for the species (J. Hart, unpublished data 2012). Methods appropriate for estimating C. hamlyni population size, such as camera trap surveys, show promise (Easton et al. 2011), but have not yet been conducted.
range:
The range of Cercopithecus hamlyni resembles that of Allochrocebus lhoesti, with a continuous EOO from the Congo/Lualaba River in the west, through the forested basins of the Lindi, Ituri, Maiko, Lowa, Ulindi and Elila rivers in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), where the bulk of the range falls, into the submontane and montane forests of the Albertine Rift, where a small portion of the range is located. The range is bounded in the north by the Lindi-Nepoko river system and in the south by the southern limit of tropical moist forest (about 4° S). The only known population outside DRC occurs in an area of about 32 km² in Rwanda's Nyungwe National Park (Easton et al. 2011). A second Rwandan population in Gishwati is now likely extirpated due to habitat loss (Hart et al. 2013). Historically, populations of C. hamlyni have been reported from several small, isolated forest blocks, south to nearly 6° S (Hart et al. 2013); however, its current status in these areas is unknown. The eastern-most highland populations of C. hamlyni are now isolated in fragmented habitat islands, some of which have been recently extirpated, such as the forest islands between Kahuzi-Biega National Park and Masisi. The species has not been reported from areas of Burundi adjoining the Nyungwe population and its possible former occurrence in Uganda is not supported by museum specimens.

We estimate that the species’ elevational range extends from 450 m, where C. hamlyni has recently been recorded east of Kindu, 40 km from the Congo/Lualaba River (Hart pers. obs. 2018), to 3,200 m on Mt. Kahuzi and Mt. Tshiaberimu (Hart et al. 2013).
useTrade: Owl-faced Monkey meat is eaten, but the contribution of this species to total bushmeat sale volume is low (J. Hart unpublished data 2018). Commerce of C. hamlyni meat is illegal (Enerunga 2006).
conservationActions:
Cercopithecus hamlyni is listed on Appendix II of CITES and is included among DRC’s nationally protected species (Enerunga 2006); however, this law is largely unenforced outside protected areas. Given current trends in habitat loss, the single most important intervention for the in situ conservation of this species is guard patrols in national parks and other protected areas.

Owl-faced Monkeys occur in several protected areas with large blocks of intact habitat, including: Kahuzi-Biega and Maiko national parks, the Itombwe Massif Nature Reserve, the Okapi Wildlife Reserve and the Tayna Reserve. A large area in the Ituri Forest (Mai Tatu Forest) also harbours this monkey (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2008, 2014), as does a small isolated forest block (North Balala) to the southeast of Itombwe (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2014). It is found in small numbers at two sites in in Virunga National Park: Watalinga Forest in the north and Mt Tshiaberimu – a remnant patch of formerly contiguous habitat now covering only 75 km². Both of these populations, as well as the population in the upland sector of Kahuzi-Biega National Park, are isolated from other populations. The small population in Rwanda's Nyungwe National Park is also isolated. Additional research on population numbers and distribution is required, so as to better focus conservation efforts.

rationale: Miss Waldron's Red Colobus is listed as Critically Endangered as the species is estimated to have undergone a population decline of more than 80% in the 30 years (approximately three generations) up until the last authenticated specimen (killed by a hunter) was found in 2002. Calls of what are believed to be this animal were heard in early 2008, but no wild animal has been seen by an experienced field-worker for 40 years. Therefore this monkey is regarded as possibly extinct. Its disappearance from its former range in the forests of eastern Côte d’Ivoire and western Ghana was almost certainly caused by excessive hunting for the bushmeat trade, combined with a loss of mature forest habitat.
habitat: Miss Waldron’s Red Colobus was restricted to tropical moist and semi-deciduous forest, and swamp forest, where it typically used the upper canopy (Martin 1991). Two groups studied in Bia National Park in Ghana in the 1970s comprised 34 and 58 individuals, had home ranges of 100–140 ha, and had a diet consisting predominantly of leaves but also fruits, seeds and flowers (Martin 1991).
threats: The major causes of the decline of the species were hunting and habitat loss (Oates et al. 2000). Both subsistence and commercial hunting (for the bushmeat trade) heavily impacted populations of this species, and improved access to forest interiors via logging roads increased hunting pressure. Deforestation through logging, charcoal production, cocoa farming and clearance for agricultural land (including industrial oil palm and rubber tree plantations), occurred over much of the species range in the last 50-60 years.
population: There have been no confirmed sightings of Miss Waldron's Red Colobus in the wild since 1978 and surveys carried out from 1993 to the present have failed to produce a sighting of living individuals (Oates et al. 2000, McGraw 2005, Oates 2011). The last evidence for the survival of a small population came from the Tanoé Swamp Forest between the Ehy lagoon and the Tanoé River in extreme south-eastern Côte d'Ivoire (McGraw and Oates 2002, McGraw 2005, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2008), near which a skin was found in possession of a hunter in 2002 and where calls by what is believed to be Miss Waldron's Red Colobus were heard in March 2008 by a team of scientists from the Centre Suisse de Recherches Scientifiques en Côte d’Ivoire (I. Koné pers. comm. 2008).
range: Piliocolobus waldroni ranged from the Nzi-Bandama River system in south-eastern Côte d'Ivoire to south-western Ghana, but did not reach the Volta River (Oates et al. 2000, McGraw 2005, Oates 2011). Its numbers were declining in Ghana 60 years ago, when Booth (1956) predicted its extinction in the near future. The last evidence for the monkey’s survival came from swamp forests between the Ehy lagoon and Tanoé River in south-eastern Côte d'Ivoire (McGraw 2005, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2008).
useTrade: This species was known to be heavily hunted.
conservationActions: This taxon is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the  African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, despite increasing hunting and persecution of this taxon. Cercopithecus agilis usually occurs at low density and a significant population decrease is suspected; however, data needed to quantify the threats and any resulting declines are lacking.
habitat:
In the west of its range, this species is generally found in riparian or periodically-flooded swamp forest (Gautier-Hion and Brugière 2005). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park in Congo, they use seasonally-inundated and riverine habitats and occasionally the Marantaceae-dominated terra firma forests (Maisels 1995, 1996). In the area east of Makokou in Gabon, they were found in riverine forests (Quris 1975). By contrast, a study group at Mondika in CAR spent most of its time in terra firma mixed forest, and was never observed along the Mondika River, nor in swamp forest along the Ndoki River (Shah 2003), whereas a group at Bai Hokou, also in CAR, spent some time along rivers and streams (N. Shah pers. obs. 2003). Cercocebus agilis also uses open-understorey Gilbertiodendron dewevrei dominated forest (Shah 2003, Devreese 2011). In the north of its range, the species will use the gallery forests in savanna-forest mosaics of northern CAR (Fay 1988), and in the east (e.g., Okapi Wildlife Reserve), it uses terra firma forests, but will sometimes forage on crops (Kambale Saambere 1999). These monkeys are usually active in lower strata (0–10 m) of the habitat (Quris 1975, Shah 2003), although they spend less time on the ground than other Cercocebus spp. (Shah 2003). Home-range size was estimated to be ca 3 km² in Dzanga-Sangha in CAR (Shah 2003), and 2 km² in Gabon (Quris 1975).

Agile Mangabeys have strong dietary preferences for fruit, seeds and monocotyledon shoots, and can bite through the hard shells of some fruits, such as Strychnos (Shah 2003). They also prey on animals up to the size of infant Peters’ Duikers (Knights et al. 2008, Shah 2013).

In CAR, mean group size was 21 at Mondika, but a habituated group at nearby Bai Hokou numbered 135 animals, and on occasion it reached 330 individuals (Devreese et al. 2013). In northeastern Gabon, group size ranged between 8 and 18 (Quris 1975). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park (Congo), group size was usually >20 (Maisels 1996). In Ituri (DRC), it was 24 (Kambale Saambili 1999), in Ngotto Forest (CAR) it was 20 (D. Brugière, pers. comm. 2013). Groups of 50–200 have been observed in southeast Cameroon (Usongo and Fimbel 1995), northeast Gabon (Quris 1975) and northeast DRC (Kambale Saambili 1999).
threats:
Cercocebus agilis is hunted throughout its range for bushmeat and sometimes persecuted for crop raiding. Because these monkeys spend a fair proportion of time on the ground, they are vulnerable to snaring – a method of hunting used throughout its geographic range. Snares are usually set for forest antelopes and rodents, but can catch any terrestrial animal.

At the western, northern and eastern edges of its range, this species is threatened by habitat loss caused by deforestation for timber and firewood. An analysis of forest loss suggests that 1.3% of the forest in its range was lost between 2001 and 2016 (13,368 km² of the 1 million km² range). However, because this taxon occurs primarily along rivers, this may be an underestimate of the true loss of habitat, as forest loss in the savanna-forest mosaic will be concentrated along rivers and galleries.
population:
Few data exist on abundance relative to human pressure, but even in 1996, in the more westerly part of its range (Lobéké NP, Cameroon), the abundance of C. agilis was an order of magnitude lower than the smaller-bodied, sympatric guenons at that site, and it was recorded only at distances of over 20 km from a road (an indicator of high hunting pressure), whereas smaller-bodied primate species still occurred close to the road (WCS unpublished data 1996). In the most easterly part of its range, in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, encounter rates on surveys declined by an order of magnitude (WCS unpublished data 2018) over the last decade. This is attributed to increased hunting pressure, due to easier access along a much-improved main road, to the influx of large numbers of people into the area for artisanal mining, and to ongoing civil unrest in eastern DRC.

Densities of Agile Mangabeys appear to be highly variable, presumably influenced by both habitat type and hunting pressure. Population density in Gabon has been recorded at between 6.7 and 12.5 individuals/km² (Quris 1975). At Mondika in Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park (Congo), density was 6.9 individuals/km² (Shah 2003). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park (Congo), group size was usually at least 20, and there were between 0.5 and 2 groups/km² (10–40 animals/km²), depending on the habitat type (Maisels 1996). In the Ituri Forest (DRC), densities varied between 2 individuals/km² (Thomas 1991) and 38 individuals/km² (Kambale Saambili 1998). In the Ngotto Forest (CAR), densities varied between 7.2 and 41 individuals/km² – variation here was related to hunting intensity by humans (D. Brugière pers. comm. 2013).
range:
The geographic range of Cercocebus agilis is not well known, despite covering about 1,010,000 km². This species occurs in Cameroon, Central African Republic (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), northeast Gabon and northern Republic of Congo. It remains to be confirmed whether it still occurs in Equatorial Guinea.

The most westerly subpopulation, which may be isolated, appears to be in Campo Ma’an in southern Cameroon, as recorded by three different surveys (Etoga and Foguekem 2008, 2009; Nzooh Dongmo 2015). The Agile Mangabey is, therefore, expected to occur in Equatorial Guinea; however, since the 1960s, when a single adult female was recorded by Sabater Pi and Jones (1968), no survey has re-confirmed the presence of this species (Larison et al. 1999, Puit and Ghiurghi 2004, Sunderland 2005, Ruffler et al. 2012).

The northerly range limit is the forest ecotone from north of the Dja Biosphere Reserve in Cameroon, perhaps at 5°N, across to the Ubangui River, the gallery forest areas in CAR, up to about 9° N (Fay 1988). East of 22° E, the northern limit is likely around 6° 45’ N across to about 30°E, including the area of DRC southwards to at least the Tshopo River.

The southern limit is the right bank of the Congo River, probably from its confluence with the Tshopo (J. Hart pers. obs.) westward to the Sangha-Congo confluence at 1°6’ S. The range is then limited by the southwestern edge of the swamp forests (around 0°18’S up to just south of Odzala National Park (NP) at about 0°30’ S, and continues westwards across Gabon to Cameroon – west of the Dja Biosphere Reserve, near Sangemelima at around 11°30’ E (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999).
useTrade: <span class="msoIns">This species is hunted throughout its range for bushmeat.
conservationActions:
Cercocebus agilis is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Nationally, it is listed as partially protected in Cameroon, Congo and DRC. The hunting, sale, and consumption of primates are forbidden in Equatorial Guinea by Presidential Decree. It is on List C of Annex 2 to Ordinance 84.045 of 1984 in CAR, and not mentioned in Gabon’s protected species list. Cameroon, Gabon and Congo are currently revising their protected species lists.

To determine the western limits of its distribution, it is recommended that people familiar with both the call and appearance of C. torquatus, C. agilis (and Lophocebus albigena) undertake surveys in Campo Ma’an National Park and the areas between there and Dja Biosphere Reserve to be sure whether or not the two Cercocebus spp. are indeed sympatric. If C. agilis is confirmed there, then it may well also still occur in Equatorial Guinea and efforts should be made to look for this species there also.

Agile Mangabeys have been recorded in a number of protected areas; here we cite only the most recent survey information available:

Cameroon: Lobéké NP (Nzooh Dongmo et al. 2016a); Boumba Bek NP and Nki NP (Nzooh Dongmo et al. 2016b); Mengame Gorilla Sanctuary (Ekobo 2006); Dja Biosphere Reserve – already uncommon in 2009 (Latour 2010) and not recorded in 2015 (MINFOF/IUCN 2015; Campo Ma’an NP (Nzooh Dongmo 2015). Not recorded in Abong Mbam or Deng Deng in 2001 (Fotso et al. 2002), nor in Deng Deng in 2012 (Maisels et al. 2013a).

CAR: Dzanga-Ndoki NP (N’Goran et al. 2016), Mbaéré-Bodingué NP (Brugière et al. 2005); Zemongo Reserve (Roulet et al. 2007), Chinko Reserve (R. Hickisch & T. Aebischer, unpublished data 2016).

Congo: Nouabalé-Ndoki NP and Lac Télé Community Reserve (Brncic et al. 2018); Odzala-Kokoua NP (Maisels et al. 2013b).

DRC: Bili-Uéré Hunting Domain (Hicks 2014), Garamba NP (Hillman-Smith et al. 2014), Okapi Wildlife Reserve (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2018).

Gabon: an early study of this species (Quris 1975) recorded its presence south of the Ivindo River (just to the east of what is now the north of Ivindo NP). C. agilis has not been recorded in protected areas of Gabon since. However, Shah (2013) mentions personal communications from well-informed scientists (L.J.T. White and S.A. Lahm) suggesting that Agile Mangabeys may still occur in Ivindo NP, Minkébé NP and Mwagna NP.

rationale: Moderately rapid declines are known to have occurred in several key areas across this species's range as a result of habitat fragmentation and degradation. Consequently it is classified as Vulnerable.
habitat: In Morocco and Tunisia, it typically occupies open plains, shrub-steppe and high steppe dotted mainly with alfa grass steppes (Stipa spp.). Abundant also in non-degraded wormwood (Artemisia spp.) and other species-mixed shrub vegetation patches, on hard or pebbly soils, avoiding sand (Isenmann and Moali 2000, Thévenot et al. 2003, Isenmann et al. 2005). In Spain, it occurs mostly in areas with low bushes (Seoane et al. 2006, Vögeli et al. 2010, Perez-Granados et al. 2017a, Gomez-Catasus et al. 2019). It may also occur in cereal fields outside the breeding season (Suárez et al. 2008). It is found from 50-1,880 m but mainly over 1,000 m. It feeds on the ground on insects and seeds. Breeding takes place in March-July (Herranz et al. 1994, Perez-Granados et al. 2017b). Breeding in the North African populations starts earlier, at the end of January-February.
threats:
In parts of its range, overgrazing or undergrazing and agricultural development have caused a reduction in its preferred habitats and a considerable decrease in numbers (M. Smart in litt. 2004, Isenmann et al. 2005, Traba et al. 2019). Reforestation schemes also lead to a loss of suitable habitat and infrastructure development has led to fragmentation of habitat, particularly by the construction and development of windfarms in Spain. In Tunisia, the fight against desertification has led to reforestation with Eucalyptus spp. and Optunia spp., which has caused a severe, rapid reduction in the halfa steppes. In Morocco, the loss of the traditional way of life for the nomadic grazers has led to increased sedentary agricultural pressures like the increase in livestock herds. 
The limited dispersal capabilities of the species and its fragmented distribution reduce the exchange of individuals between populations and increases their extinction risk (Méndez et al. 2014).  

The shrinking of its available habitat may be leading to territory saturation, which in turn can lead to agonistic behaviour and nest failure (Vögeli et al. 2010; Pérez-Granados and López-Iborra 2013, 2015). A recent Spanish study has shown that the species's occurrence is principally determined by geographic isolation (extinction events were exclusively related to isolation), landscape matrix and patch size, rather than habitat quality (Vögeli et al. 2010). Isolation of local populations and reduced patch size has a compounding effect on population density since smaller populations suffer reduced singing repertoires which in turn reduce the rescuing from others (receiving immigrants), thus compromising population persistence (Laiolo and Tella 2008, Pérez-Granados et al. 2016). Wildfires can lead to the local extirpation of the species (Pérez-Granados et al. 2013b), although they can have long term benefits (Perez-Granados et al. 2018b). Additionally, wind farms may have negative impacts on the distribution of this lark (Gomez-Catasus et al. 2018b). Political unrest in some of its range may be impacting the species, but the effect this has had on the species is essentially unknown (D. Serrano and J. Traba in litt. 2016). Solar farms have also demonstrated negative effects on local occupancy and persistence of the species (Gomez-Catasus et al. 2018b).
population:
García et al. (2008) estimate 15,400 singing males in Morocco, while in Spain the most recent estimate suggests around 3,700-4,000 males (Traba et al. 2019). The Tunisian population was estimated to be c.600 singing males in 2007 (Suarez, Garcia and Vinuela in litt. 2020).

It has a 0.61 male-biased sex ratio, and the global estimate is currently placed between 25,000 – 35,000 individuals (J García pers. comm. 2020, J Traba pers. comm. 2020).
